resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent non-tariff barriers (NTBs) hindering the single market’s full potential, estimating that eliminating these could yield annual economic gains of €651 billion to €1.1 trillion (5%-8.63% of EU GDP). Despite the single market’s foundational role, NTBs—including disproportionate national regulations, bureaucratic hurdles, and inconsistent enforcement—continue to impede cross-border trade, particularly in services (70% of the EU economy but only 20% of intra-EU trade) and digital sectors (potential €415 billion annual gain by 2020). Key challenges include fragmented VAT regimes, low cross-border public procurement (3.5% of contracts), and barriers for SMEs (only 2% expanding cross-border). The resolution urged swift implementation of the Digital Single Market and Single Market Strategies, emphasizing harmonization, mutual recognition, and streamlined tools like improved Single Points of Contact, SOLVIT, and VAT Mini One-Stop Shop (MOSS). It called for stronger enforcement of existing rules, addressing "gold-plating" in national legislation, and enhancing e-governance (e.g., digital signatures, interoperable systems). Sector-specific measures included reforming services directives, reducing construction and retail barriers, and ensuring affordable cross-border parcel delivery. The Commission was tasked with presenting a comprehensive NTB analysis by 2016, prioritizing infringement procedures for non-compliance, and fostering a compliance culture to unlock the single market’s untapped potential for consumers and businesses.

title: Sign language and professional sign language interpreters: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on sign languages and professional sign language interpreters
background: Persistent disparities in accessibility for deaf and hard-of-hearing citizens across EU member states, coupled with inconsistent recognition of sign languages and insufficient availability of qualified interpreters, have raised concerns regarding compliance with disability rights frameworks and language equality obligations. The Parliament will discuss measures to enhance sign language accessibility and professional interpreter standards within the EU.

stances.stance:
EPP fundamentally upholds the issue's recognition of sign language interpretation as a fundamental right enabling full societal participation, perfectly aligning with EPP's equality principles.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for bilingual education systems and early childhood sign language acquisition programs to eliminate systemic disadvantages for deaf students.  
EPP fully supports institutionalizing the INSIGN project as a permanent EU framework to guarantee real-time sign language services across all member states.  
EPP strongly advocates for binding EU-wide standards requiring professional interpreters in healthcare, justice, and emergency services to fulfill accessibility obligations.  
EPP endorses designating sign languages as official EU languages and mandating interpreter availability at all parliamentary sessions to set global inclusivity benchmarks.

ENF supports the issue’s emphasis on granting sign language interpreters equal professional status within EU institutions, aligning with their commitment to social justice for deaf communities.  
ENF advises expanding access to sign language education by mandating its inclusion in national university curricula across all member states to strengthen societal solidarity.  
ENF highlights the need for more ambitious integration measures, such as employment initiatives and accessible public services, to fully address systemic barriers faced by deaf individuals.  
ENF endorses standardized data collection on interpretation services but urges faster implementation to ensure timely policy adjustments.  
ENF commends bilingual education provisions but recommends explicit funding mechanisms to guarantee consistent quality and availability.

GREEN_EFA totally endorses the issue’s emphasis on sign language accessibility as a fundamental right, perfectly aligning with their commitment to linguistic justice and disability inclusion.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for EU pressure on Member States to address interpreter shortages, mirroring Terry Reintke’s urgent example of 120 interpreters for 12 000 deaf citizens in North Rhine-Westphalia.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s alignment with their manifesto priorities by demanding trained interpreters as non-negotiable for societal participation, education, and public services.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the push for bilingual education with qualified teachers, directly addressing systemic gaps Reintke experienced and advancing intersectional equity.  
GREEN_EFA affirms the issue’s insistence on EU institutional leadership, ensuring sign language parity in multilingualism policies and emergency communication standards.

ALDE firmly advocates the issue’s integration of professional sign language interpretation as a non-negotiable accessibility requirement, perfectly aligning with ALDE’s commitment to eliminating systemic barriers under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the demand for formal recognition of national sign languages, exemplified by their active support for Ireland’s campaign to codify Irish Sign Language and ensure its parity in education, healthcare, and judicial systems.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s focus on Erasmus+ accessibility for deaf communities, reflecting ALDE’s longstanding priority to expand inclusive mobility programs that align with Article 24 of the UN Convention.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for standardized interpreter-to-user ratios across Member States, directly reinforcing the issue’s call for minimum accessibility standards in digital and emergency communication frameworks.  
ALDE commends the insistence on EU institutional leadership in sign language equality, mirroring their advocacy for binding multilingualism policies that treat sign languages as equal to spoken languages.

SD fully accepts the issue’s emphasis on linguistic equality, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to dismantling barriers for deaf and hard-of-hearing citizens through robust recognition of sign languages as fundamental rights under EU treaties.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call to standardize professional sign language interpreter training, reflecting SD’s priority to ensure quality education and employment accessibility across healthcare, justice, and public services.  
SD fully accepts integrating sign languages into EU multilingualism policies, advancing SD’s vision of inclusive political participation and cultural exchange as exemplified by the motto “Unita nella diversità.”  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for Eurostat data collection to address interpreter shortages, resonating with SD’s focus on evidence-based solutions to achieve equitable interpreter-to-user ratios.  
SD fully accepts the critique of the European Disability Card Pilot Project’s exclusion of sign language services, reinforcing SD’s stance on mobility rights and accessible Erasmus+ programs for all.

ECR strongly upholds the issue’s prioritization of professional sign language interpreters, aligning perfectly with ECR's longstanding commitment to linguistic equality and disability rights under the UN Convention and EU Charter.  
ECR applauds the focus on standardized training and equitable pay for interpreters, emphasizing the urgent need to reduce the EU-wide shortage of 1:160 interpreters through member state-led educational initiatives.  
ECR proposes enhancing the EU institutions’ leadership by formally integrating qualified sign language interpreters into permanent staffing structures, ensuring accessibility during legislative and public engagements.  
ECR emphasizes the issue’s milestone status in advancing bilingual education and data-driven policies, which directly empower deaf citizens’ participation in civic and professional spheres.  
ECR underscores the necessity of binding accessibility standards for digital services and emergency communication, reflecting the urgency of eliminating systemic barriers faced by 52 million deaf and hard-of-hearing Europeans.

GUE_NGL firmly approves the issue’s recognition of professional sign language interpreters as a fundamental accessibility measure, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eradicating systemic discrimination against deaf communities.  
GUE_NGL highlights the urgency of political will to institutionalize sign language rights across EU bodies, advancing their principle that linguistic equality is inseparable from democratic participation.  
GUE_NGL applauds the demand for qualified interpreters’ equitable remuneration, reinforcing their manifesto priority to combat labor exploitation in marginalized professions.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the call for binding accessibility standards in digital communication, a critical step toward their vision of universal public service inclusion.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes the issue’s alignment with UNCRPD obligations, urging immediate implementation to eliminate electoral barriers for deaf citizens as a human rights imperative.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to ensure full accessibility and equal rights for deaf, hard-of-hearing, and deafblind citizens, emphasizing sign language as a fundamental right under EU treaties, the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. It highlighted that approximately 1 million deaf sign language users and 51 million hard-of-hearing individuals in the EU face systemic barriers, including insufficient access to qualified sign language interpreters, with ratios ranging from 8:1 to 2,500:1 (average 160:1) per user. The resolution stressed the necessity of professional sign language interpretation as a critical accessibility measure or reasonable accommodation in education, employment, healthcare, justice, and public services, noting disparities in TV subtitling (10%-100% coverage) and the lack of standardized interpretation data. It urged Member States to promote sign language learning, ensure bilingual education with qualified interpreters, and adopt minimum accessibility standards for digital and emergency communication. The EU institutions were called to lead by example, providing equal status for sign language interpreters, improving staff accommodations, and implementing projects like INSIGN for real-time sign language services. It also criticized the exclusion of sign language interpretation from the European Disability Card Pilot Project, which hinders mobility, and emphasized the need for inclusive Erasmus+ programs, accessible political processes, and data collection via Eurostat to inform policy. The resolution underscored that accessibility and reasonable accommodation are complementary obligations, with disproportionality claims invalidating denial of access, and affirmed sign languages’ linguistic equality, urging their integration into EU multilingualism policies.

title: Single Market Governance within the European Semester 2017: REPORT on the Annual Report on the Single Market Governance within the European Semester 2017
background: Persistent fragmentation and uneven implementation of EU Single Market rules, coupled with slow post-2008 crisis recovery, high unemployment, and Brexit's impact on cross-border trade, prompted calls for enhanced economic governance. The Parliament will discuss integrating Single Market performance monitoring into the European Semester framework to strengthen structural reforms and market integration.

stances.stance:
EPP completely advocates the issue's integration of a robust Single Market pillar with social dimensions, perfectly aligning with EPP's longstanding commitment to economic convergence through SME competitiveness and digital transformation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for systematic elimination of non-tariff barriers, emphasizing the €600 billion growth potential cited in the issue through enhanced use of the Single Market Scoreboard and infringement procedures.  
EPP fully supports strict enforcement of public procurement rules and VAT reforms, mirroring Burkhard Balz's insistence on fiscal discipline and Tom Vandenkendelaere's praise for EFSI-driven investment outcomes.  
EPP perfectly endorses the issue's digital governance priorities, reinforcing Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein's demand for modernized administrations and cross-border digital service integration via existing portals like "Your Europe."  
EPP fully backs the social fairness imperative, amplifying Heinz K. Becker's focus on dual education systems and youth guarantee programs to achieve the issue's 15% NEET reduction target.

EFDD rejects the issue's failure to address Germany’s chronic current account surplus exceeding 6% GDP threshold under Macroeconomic Imbalance Procedure (MIP), directly conflicting with EFDD’s demand for binding surplus corrections to prevent Single Market disintegration.  
EFDD opposes fundamentally the assumption that deeper integration alone resolves structural flaws, citing the euro’s fixed exchange regime as artificially undervaluing Germany’s currency to fuel export dominance at others’ expense.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects like Germany’s non-compliance with Commission MIP recommendations, which EFDD deems central to resolving internal EU trade asymmetries eroding market cohesion.  
EFDD condemns the issue’s silence on reforming monetary architecture, which perpetuates Germany’s "currency undervaluation" advantage since 1999 – a contradiction to proclaimed goals of level playing fields and SME growth.  
 EFDD argues the Single Market Scoreboard and VAT reforms ignore root causes: fixed exchange rates enabling surplus-driven imbalances that "disintegrate" cross-border opportunities for SMEs.

ENF rejects the integration of social dialogue as a precondition for labor market reforms, fully opposeing with ENF's position that such conditions obstruct necessary structural adjustments.  
ENF opposes fundamentally the issue's endorsement of ECB quantitative easing policies, which they deem contradictory and detrimental to addressing sovereign debt crises.  
ENF condemns the issue's failure to prioritize European citizens in social funding, highlighting its inconsistency with ENF's stance against migrant labor market integration via EU instruments like the Youth Guarantee.  
ENF dismisses the "social pillar" as a deceptive tool to legitimize austerity-driven governance, arguing it entrenches supranational control over national economic policies.  
ENF challenges the issue's claim of fostering growth through Single Market integration, citing persistent unemployment and systemic deregulation as evidence of its alignment with harmful ultra-liberal agendas.

GREEN_EFA firmly supports the issue's integration of a robust social dimension into the Single Market governance framework, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that economic convergence must prioritize reducing income inequality and gender-based discrimination.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the emphasis on inclusive growth, particularly the call to address systemic barriers for disadvantaged groups, which mirrors their longstanding commitment to eradicating opportunity gaps rooted in social class and ensuring living wages.  
GREEN_EFA firmly supports the issue’s focus on modernizing social security systems and lifelong learning, advancing their manifesto goals to equip workers with STEM/digital skills and secure decent work-life balance in evolving labor markets.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly supports the prioritization of stakeholder engagement and corrective action for Member States, reflecting their advocacy for participatory governance to tackle child poverty through guarantees like housing and education investments.  
GREEN_EFA firmly supports leveraging the Investment Plan for Europe to deepen market integration while ensuring social fairness, a strategy they champion to create jobs through sustainable infrastructure and combat in-work poverty.

ALDE fundamentally advocates the issue's strict enforcement mechanisms for Single Market rules, perfectly aligning with their commitment to regulatory stability and investor confidence as emphasized by Lieve Wierinck's insistence on compliance.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the integration of social fairness into market governance, supporting Enrique Calvet Chambon's demand to center policies on employment quality and inequality reduction through rigorous macroeconomic evaluations.  
ALDE strongly promotes systematic barrier monitoring against protectionism, echoing Dita Charanzová's call to safeguard cross-border opportunities in both traditional and collaborative economies.  
ALDE endorses the development of intergenerational budget sustainability indicators, viewing Lieve Wierinck's proposal as a critical enhancement to ensure fiscal transparency for future generations without opposing the issue's core objectives.  
ALDE applauds the push for official Single Market integration metrics, aligning with Dita Charanzová's emphasis on leveraging national success stories like the Czech Republic to accelerate economic convergence.

SD firmly sanctions the issue's integration of a robust Single Market pillar with social dimensions, perfectly aligning with S&D's demand for youth employment guarantees, social security sustainability, and collective bargaining rights as essential components of economic governance.  

SD perfectly aligns with the issue's call for expansionary fiscal policies, endorsing the shift from austerity to coordinated public investment in sustainable infrastructure and social services as emphasized by multiple S&D speakers in their critique of stagnant growth models.  

SD firmly sanctions the issue's emphasis on eliminating non-tariff barriers and digital market integration, recognizing these as prerequisites for achieving the €600 billion annual growth potential while ensuring SME competitiveness and cross-border labor mobility.  

SD perfectly aligns with the issue's governance improvements through enhanced market surveillance and Single Market Scoreboard utilization, directly addressing S&D members' concerns about uneven application of EU rules and territorial disparities in investment attraction.  

SD firmly sanctions the issue's linkage between social fairness and economic convergence, mirroring S&D's insistence on binding measures to reduce gender pay gaps, pension disparities, and child poverty through EU-wide social protection frameworks.

ECR strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on eliminating non-tariff barriers and advancing the Digital Single Market, aligning with their commitment to market efficiency and SME competitiveness.  
ECR applauds the focus on regulatory predictability and national sovereignty in economic governance, which resonates with their advocacy for diverse fiscal models exemplified by Poland’s growth outside the eurozone.  
ECR proposes enhancing the social dimension by prioritizing active family policies and youth employment initiatives over prescriptive gender equality mandates, ensuring respect for national competencies in social reforms.  
ECR urges equitable macroeconomic governance to address imbalances, advocating for scrutiny of excessive trade surpluses and rejecting austerity-driven measures that disproportionately affect southern eurozone economies.  
ECR endorses leveraging the Investment Plan for Europe to deepen market integration while maintaining fiscal discipline, reflecting their emphasis on sustainable growth and anti-protectionist principles.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the issue's reliance on Single Market integration as incompatible with dismantling neoliberal austerity frameworks.  
GUE_NGL opposes the European Semester's governance model for perpetuating economic divergence through enforced privatization and deregulation, contrary to social cohesion claims.  
This proposal conflicts irreconcilably with GUE_NGL's demand to prioritize social charters over economic freedoms, as it subordinates worker protections to capital mobility.  
The issue's "social dimension" overlooks systemic harms caused by Eurozone constraints, which GUE_NGL identifies as requiring member-state liberation from fiscal austerity treaties.  
GUE_NGL condemns the failure to address debt crises exacerbated by Single Market rules, advocating instead for sovereign monetary policies rejected by the issue's convergence mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to strengthen the Single Market as a cornerstone of the EU, emphasizing its fragmented state and untapped potential for growth, innovation, and job creation, particularly for SMEs, start-ups, and youth. It called for integrating a robust Single Market pillar with a social dimension into the European Semester, including systematic monitoring of country-specific barriers, compliance enforcement, and evaluation of market integration to foster economic convergence and address high unemployment. Key priorities included eliminating non-tariff barriers (NTBs)—noting over 5,500 regulated professions and a 2014 study estimating €600 billion annual gains from deeper integration—advancing the Digital Single Market, and ensuring free movement of goods, services, and capital. The resolution urged timely implementation of public procurement rules, e-procurement, and a fraud-proof VAT system, alongside measures to combat protectionism and discriminatory practices. It stressed governance improvements through tools like the Single Market Scoreboard, better regulation principles, and enhanced market surveillance to remove non-compliant products. Social fairness, consumer protection, and inclusive growth were highlighted, alongside calls for modernizing public administrations, promoting digital services, and leveraging the Investment Plan for Europe to deepen market integration while ensuring regulatory predictability and a level playing field. The Commission was urged to prioritize enforcement, early intervention, and infringement procedures where necessary, alongside initiatives like the Single Digital Gateway and collaborative economy support to unlock cross-border opportunities.

title: Single Market governance within the European Semester 2016: REPORT on the Single Market governance within the European Semester 2016
background: The European Union faced post-financial crisis challenges including sluggish growth, high unemployment, and uneven Single Market integration, compounded by global competition and incomplete implementation of existing legislation. The Parliament will discuss enhancing Single Market governance within the European Semester framework to strengthen economic coordination, competitiveness, and structural reforms across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, aligning perfectly with their longstanding commitment to strengthening Single Market competitiveness through targeted country-specific recommendations.  
EPP applauds the focus on SME growth and digital modernization, which effectively advances their priority of reducing bureaucratic barriers while fostering innovation through cross-border e-commerce and e-administration reforms.  
EPP endorses systematic monitoring of Services Directive implementation, proposing enhanced stakeholder engagement to address geo-blocking and non-tariff barriers without opposing the issue’s core governance framework.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of upgrading interoperability standards and high-speed networks, strongly backing the Digital Single Market Strategy as critical to bridging technological divides between member states.  
EPP welcomes the integration of employment indicators into the European Semester process, aligning with their social market principles to ensure economic growth translates into job creation and social convergence.

EFDD rejects the issue's uncritical endorsement of eurozone governance, stating it "firmly disputes with EFDD's position that the euro creates structural unemployment and economic stagnation."  
EFDD opposes the assumption that Single Market integration offsets currency union flaws, citing UK's post-2008 job retention through pound flexibility versus eurozone's "millions lost."  
EFDD dismisses claims about the Digital Single Market's potential, arguing the issue "overlooks critical aspects" like euro-induced macroeconomic imbalances stifling SME growth.  
EFDD condemns continued emphasis on structural reforms and fiscal consolidation as "inconsistent with EFDD's principles," noting youth unemployment proves austerity's failure.  
EFDD rejects CSR monitoring mechanisms as inadequate, demanding instead "true policy reversal" addressing euro's role in trade imbalances and debt crises.

ENF rejects the issue's emphasis on Single Market integration as entirely disputeing with their opposition to centralized EU economic governance and erosion of national sovereignty.  
ENF opposes the Digital Single Market Strategy, arguing it overlooks critical aspects like protecting European industries from external competition and exacerbates labor market instability through unregulated migration.  
ENF condemns the call for stricter enforcement mechanisms, citing the European Semester's failure to address mass unemployment and debt crises while imposing austerity incompatible with national economic priorities.  
ENF disputes the issue's growth assumptions, asserting that EU policies have directly caused industrial decline and that further market liberalization will accelerate deindustrialization.  
ENF totally rejects CSR-based governance as a tool of financial totalitarianism, rejecting alignment with EU fiscal rules that prioritize debt reduction over sovereign economic protectionism.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's failure to mandate circular economy principles and resource efficiency targets despite Parliament's explicit 2015 directives.  
GREEN_EFA opposes fundamentally the omission of market surveillance mechanisms for product safety violations, particularly after Dieselgate exposed systemic regulatory failures.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposal's linkage of cohesion funding to economic governance conditions as punitive and counterproductive to equitable development.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the absence of binding fiscal harmonization measures to combat tax avoidance schemes revealed by LuxLeaks.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's silence on gender pay gap closure timelines and inadequate social investment thresholds for healthcare and childcare systems.

ALDE absolutely promotes the issue’s prioritization of structural reforms over fiscal expansion, perfectly aligning with their commitment to improving business environments and mobilizing private investment.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on modernizing the Single Market through digital integration, endorsing accelerated implementation of the Digital Single Market Strategy and upgraded interoperability frameworks.  
ALDE absolutely promotes the call for economically viable EFSI projects, reflecting their principle that investments must avoid wasteful infrastructure and prioritize market-driven growth.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with strengthening Single Market governance through rigorous enforcement of mutual recognition principles and product safety legislation, advancing their agenda for barrier-free competition.  
ALDE absolutely promotes the issue’s focus on SME growth and cross-border e-commerce, recognizing its synergy with their advocacy for reduced bureaucratic barriers and labor market reforms.

SD strongly promotes the integration of Single Market governance with social progress, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to holistic economic policies that prioritize high-quality jobs and consumer protection alongside market efficiency.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on strategic public investment as critical to reversing austerity-driven stagnation, proposing enhanced coordination between the European Fund for Strategic Investments and national programs to maximize multiplier effects.  
SD endorses the call to address child poverty and gender pay gaps through targeted EU funding mechanisms, urging explicit inclusion of these priorities in country-specific recommendations to strengthen social cohesion.  
SD approves the Digital Single Market modernization agenda, particularly its focus on SME-friendly e-commerce frameworks, which directly advances SD's 2016 priorities for innovation-led growth and cross-border entrepreneurship.  
SD suggests refining monitoring mechanisms to include quarterly assessments of social inequality metrics alongside economic indicators, ensuring compliance with the issue’s inclusive governance principles without opposing its core structure.

ECR strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on reducing bureaucratic barriers and enhancing SME competitiveness, aligning perfectly with ECR’s longstanding commitment to national sovereignty and market-driven growth.  
ECR approves the focus on digital modernization and interoperability frameworks, proposing an amendment to explicitly safeguard member states’ regulatory autonomy in technical standardization processes.  
ECR endorses the call for improved stakeholder engagement in annual assessments, urging concrete mechanisms to prioritize SME input in line with subsidiarity principles.  
ECR welcomes measures to address geo-blocking and services directive implementation as critical to market integration, while advocating stricter subsidiarity checks to avoid centralized enforcement overreach.  
ECR highlights the importance of recognizing defense spending contributions within fiscal responsibility assessments, ensuring balanced evaluations of member states’ economic priorities.

GUE/NGL fundamentally rejects the issue's endorsement of the European Semester framework as it institutionalizes neoliberal austerity policies that exacerbate social inequalities and dismantle public welfare systems.  
GUE/NGL opposes the promotion of labor market flexicurity measures in the issue, which directly contradict the party's commitment to workers' rights by normalizing precarious employment and wage suppression.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's failure to address the arbitrary enforcement of fiscal rules that disproportionately target southern European states, mirroring the critique of discriminatory treatment toward Portugal and Greece raised in debates.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue's dangerous alignment with corporate interests through its emphasis on digital market liberalization, which neglects essential social protections and public sector safeguards demanded by the party.  
GUE/NGL denounces the issue's implicit validation of austerity-driven "investment" strategies that prioritize market competitiveness over concrete social infrastructure development and poverty eradication.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of the Single Market as a cornerstone of the EU, emphasizing its economic benefits, including product standardization, market integration, economies of scale, and enhanced competition for 500 million consumers. It stressed the need to address persistent non-tariff barriers, such as deficient implementation of the Services Directive (affecting 45% of EU GDP and employment) and unjustified geo-blocking, while advocating for stronger governance, compliance, and enforcement mechanisms, including systematic monitoring via country-specific recommendations (CSRs) to unlock growth and competitiveness. The resolution highlighted the urgency of modernizing the Single Market to adapt to digital and technological advancements, calling for swift implementation of the Digital Single Market Strategy, upgraded interoperability frameworks, and investment in high-speed networks to bridge the digital divide. It welcomed initiatives like the Single Market Strategy and the European Fund for Strategic Investments but expressed concern over low implementation rates of past CSRs (2011-2014), urging the Commission to create incentives for member states to act. The Parliament also underscored the importance of fostering SME growth, innovation, and cross-border e-commerce, while advocating for reforms in public procurement, e-administration, and regulatory frameworks to reduce bureaucratic barriers. It called for annual assessments of Single Market integration, improved stakeholder engagement, and stronger enforcement tools, including infringement procedures, to address non-compliance and market surveillance gaps, particularly in product safety. The resolution emphasized the need for inclusive, transparent governance and synergies between EU policies to maximize the Single Market’s potential in driving sustainable growth, job creation, and global competitiveness.

title: Single market governance within the European Semester 2015: REPORT on Single Market governance within the European Semester 2015
background: Following prolonged economic stagnation and uneven recovery post-2008 crisis, the European Semester's coordination framework faced challenges in stimulating growth, reducing unemployment, and addressing structural reforms. Persistent gaps in Single Market integration, particularly in digital and energy sectors, hindered competitiveness. The Parliament will discuss enhancing Single Market governance within the European Semester to strengthen economic recovery and convergence.

EPP fundamentally advocates the issue's integration of Single Market governance into the European Semester, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to structural reforms and fiscal discipline as drivers of sustainable growth.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for accelerated Digital Single Market implementation, emphasizing harmonized regulations and cross-border data flows to unlock €415 billion annual economic potential by 2030.  
EPP fundamentally advocates strict enforcement of Stability and Growth Pact rules across all Member States, reflecting EPP's principle of equal treatment and accountability in fiscal consolidation.  
EPP fully supports leveraging Horizon Europe and SME financing mechanisms to drive innovation, mirroring EPP's manifesto priorities for job creation and competitiveness.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the Energy Union completion targets, advocating grid interconnections and renewable integration to achieve 55% emissions reduction while ensuring affordability.

EFDD requests revisions to Innovation Fund allocations to prioritize microenterprises, countering Marco Valli’s assertion that ECB policies favor banks over SMEs in vulnerable economies.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the integration of social equity metrics into structural reform assessments, proposing to replace austerity-driven competitiveness models with frameworks prioritizing public service investment and wage growth.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s alignment with sustainable energy transitions but urges explicit binding timelines for phasing out fossil fuel subsidies in Article 4 to strengthen the 55% emissions reduction target.  

GREEN_EFA endorses the digital single market provisions while advocating for amendments to guarantee net neutrality principles in cross-border data flow regulations, ensuring equitable access for SMEs and consumers.  

GREEN_EFA highlights the need to synchronize the Innovation Fund’s allocations with circular economy priorities, transforming the “competitive gains” narrative into measurable resource-efficiency benchmarks.  

GREEN_EFA proposes expanding Horizon Europe’s scope to include mandatory social impact assessments for all infrastructure projects funded under the Juncker Plan replacement mechanism.

ALDE completely advocates the issue's prioritization of the Digital Single Market as a growth catalyst, perfectly aligning with their agenda to eliminate regulatory fragmentation and accelerate cross-border data flows for €415 billion annual economic potential.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the Energy Union completion targets, emphasizing grid interconnections and renewable integration as essential to achieving both climate goals and cost-competitive energy security.  
ALDE strongly promotes the European Semester's enhanced focus on export-import balance mechanisms, viewing coordinated investment policies as critical to reversing structural competitiveness declines in southern member states.  
ALDE applauds the issue's data-driven approach to Single Market governance, particularly its demand for analytical tools to measure regulatory performance and fast-track reforms in underperforming sectors.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of maintaining strict focus on market integration within the Semester process, ensuring surplus economy activation measures remain central to growth strategies while avoiding ideological dilution.

SD completely advocates the issue's integration of digital infrastructure investments with robust consumer protection frameworks, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to a socially equitable Digital Single Market.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's directive to prioritize Juncker Fund allocations for regions with highest unemployment, ensuring cohesion policy integration becomes a structural growth driver.  
SD completely advocates binding requirements for social dialogue mechanisms in structural reform assessments, preventing labor standard erosion while advancing service sector liberalization.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's operationalization of fiscal transfer mechanisms between surplus and deficit states, actualizing the solidarity principle in economic governance.  
SD completely advocates Horizon Europe's repurposing to prioritize green transition technologies while maintaining strict anti-austerity conditionality for public investment programs.

ECR strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on completing the Digital Single Market, aligning with their commitment to free-market principles and cross-border competitiveness.  
ECR proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly safeguard member states’ fiscal sovereignty, ensuring European Semester recommendations remain advisory rather than binding.  
ECR approves the focus on SME growth but urges deletion of references to harmonized employment laws to prevent one-size-fits-all approaches inconsistent with national labor markets.

GUE_NGL rejects fundamentally the European Semester's austerity framework as it perpetuates destructive neoliberal agendas conflicting with social equity

GUE_NGL condemns the governance model for accelerating wealth transfer from workers to capital through imposed fiscal rules violating national sovereignty

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical need to strengthen the Single Market as a foundation for economic resilience and growth within the European Semester framework, emphasizing its role in addressing structural challenges and enhancing competitiveness. It highlighted untapped potential in key sectors, particularly the Digital Single Market, urging accelerated implementation of digital infrastructure, harmonized regulations, and cross-border data flows to unlock €415 billion annually in economic gains by 2030. In energy, the resolution called for completing the Energy Union, increasing renewable energy integration, and achieving a 55% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2030, alongside targeted investments in grid interconnections and energy storage to ensure affordability and security. It stressed the importance of addressing market fragmentation, improving SME access to finance, and fostering innovation through Horizon Europe and the Innovation Fund, with specific emphasis on leveraging the Single Market to support green and digital transitions while ensuring social cohesion and equitable growth across member states.

title: Personal protective equipment: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on personal protective equipment
background: Existing EU personal protective equipment standards established in 1989 required modernization to address technological advancements and safety risks from non-compliant products entering the single market. The Parliament will discuss regulatory updates to harmonize safety requirements ensuring user protection and effective market functioning.

stances.stance:
EPP fully approves the harmonized safety standards for life-saving equipment under Category III expansion, perfectly aligning with their commitment to consumer protection and single market efficiency.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the exclusion of artisanal products and domestic gloves from scope, upholding the principle of proportionate regulation for low-risk scenarios.  
EPP fully approves the digital accessibility of Declarations of Conformity, recognizing its alignment with modern trade practices and SME-friendly measures.  
EPP fully supports the clarified employer obligations in Recital 21, which advance workplace safety priorities central to EPP's social market values.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s market surveillance enhancements, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for fraud-resistant single market governance.

EFDD slightly supports digital Declaration of Conformity access but requests explicit safeguards in Article 3.1.c to prevent overclassification of components.  
EFDD opposes Article 2.2b’s inclusion of sporting equipment as PPE, deeming it regulatory overreach inconsistent with subsidiarity principles.  
EFDD highlights the issue’s harmonization mandate firmly condemns with their opposition to EU-imposed standards, particularly citing forced UK adoption.  
EFDD requests revision to Recital 21 to exempt low-risk private-use PPE (e.g., oven gloves) from compliance burdens, aligning with proportionality claims.  
EFDD argues expansion of Category III to diving gear (Article 3) overlooks national discretion needs, contradicting EFDD’s stance against one-size-fits-all EU rules.

ALDE fundamentally upholds the harmonization of PPE standards across the EU single market, as this issue perfectly aligns with their commitment to eliminating unnecessary regulatory fragmentation and enhancing consumer safety through unified technical requirements.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the exclusion of artisanal products and non-essential private-use PPE like oven gloves, which reflects their pragmatic approach to avoiding over-regulation while maintaining rigorous protections for high-risk scenarios.  
ALDE strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on digital accessibility for Declarations of Conformity, advancing their priority of modernizing EU administrative processes to reduce burdens on businesses.  
ALDE applauds the expanded classification of Category III PPE to cover diving gear and radiation protection, effectively advancing their goal of ensuring cutting-edge safety standards for high-risk occupational environments.  
ALDE commends the issue’s proportionality in tying administrative obligations to safety risks, which aligns with their principle of minimizing bureaucratic hurdles for low-risk products while prioritizing robust oversight where lives are at stake.

SD entirely advocates the issue’s expansion of Category III protections, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to safeguarding workers facing extreme risks like chemical exposure and radiation.  
SD applauds the exclusion of non-essential private-use PPE from regulation, which advances SD’s priority of proportionate governance while maintaining strict safety guarantees for explicitly marketed protective gear.  
SD highlights the issue’s balance in reducing bureaucratic burdens for low-risk products like dishwashing gloves as a model for SD’s broader agenda on smart regulation.  
SD recognizes the strengthened market surveillance and digital conformity declarations as critical advancements, reflecting SD’s push for modernized trade frameworks that protect consumers without stifling innovation.  
SD affirms that the issue’s clarity on employer obligations and field-testing protocols delivers on SD’s manifesto pledge to harmonize safety standards with practical workplace realities.

ECR strongly approves the exclusion of non-essential PPE for private use, aligning with their commitment to reducing regulatory overreach and protecting small businesses from disproportionate compliance costs, as demonstrated in their defense of historic infrastructure exemptions.  
ECR applauds the expanded Category III protections against chemical and biological risks, which advance their priority of addressing safety gaps in imported equipment linked to globalized production chains.  
ECR endorses mandatory digital access to Declarations of Conformity, reinforcing their advocacy for modernized trade frameworks that balance transparency with administrative efficiency.  
ECR proposes enhancing Recital 21 to explicitly reference SME support mechanisms when clarifying employer obligations, ensuring proportionality in safety compliance for smaller enterprises.  
ECR strongly approves stringent importer notification requirements, consistent with their focus on preventing substandard goods from entering EU markets, particularly those endangering economically vulnerable regions.

GUE_NGL rejects the exclusion of PPE for private use against dampness and water as dangerously narrowing worker protections mandated in Recital 21  
GUE_NGL opposes the 10-year documentation rule in Article 29.2 as creating bureaucratic loopholes inconsistent with their demand for strict safety accountability  
GUE_NGL entirely disapproves with provisions burdening SMEs through expanded category III classifications of artisanal products under Article 2.2b  
The issue fails to address GUE_NGL's core demand for harmonized language regimes across all PPE warnings, risking fragmented consumer information  
GUE_NGL condemns the prioritization of market efficiency over workplace safety evident in the chemical/radiation protection exemptions under revised Article 3.1.c

resolution: The European Parliament raised key amendments to the regulation on personal protective equipment (PPE), including expanding category III to cover equipment protecting against oxygen deficiency (e.g., diving gear), chemicals, biological agents, and radiation/radioactive contamination. It introduced definitions for "demonstration" and "field test," allowing field testing under Articles 7.2–3, and classified connection systems as essential PPE components (Article 3.1.c). Importers and distributors must notify manufacturers and authorities of non-conforming PPE risks, while member states must inform manufacturers if notified bodies cease operations (Article 29.2). Transparent and accessible appeal procedures were mandated (Article 32). The resolution excluded PPE for private use against non-extreme atmospheric conditions, dampness, or water (e.g., oven gloves) unless explicitly marketed as protective, and excluded artisanal products. The Declaration of Conformity was updated to allow digital access alongside paper copies. A new chapter aligned the regulation with upcoming market surveillance rules, and employers’ obligations to provide compliant PPE were clarified (Recital 21). Sporting equipment was included as PPE (Article 2.2b), and linguistic revisions improved clarity (Recitals 11–12). Administrative burdens were tied to safety risks, ensuring proportionality for low-risk private-use PPE.

title: Promoting fairness and transparency for business users of online intermediation services: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on promoting fairness and transparency for business users of online intermediation services
background: The rapid expansion of online intermediation services, critical for SMEs accessing digital markets, raised concerns over unregulated platform dominance and opaque contractual terms disadvantaging business users. The Parliament will discuss regulatory measures to ensure fair and transparent commercial relations between platforms and business users.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the harmonized EU rules for online intermediation services, aligning perfectly with their commitment to a unified digital market that empowers SMEs across borders.  
EPP applauds the issue’s prevention of abusive platform terms, effectively advancing their priority to balance power dynamics between global platforms and European businesses.  
EPP endorses the cross-border legal clarity in Article 2, eliminating jurisdictional fragmentation and ensuring SMEs operate under predictable EU-wide standards.  
EPP proposes enhancing transparency in dispute issue mechanisms by mandating quarterly reporting on platform compliance, reinforcing accountability without opposing the core framework.  
EPP commends the Parliament’s rejection of external lobbying influences, reflecting their longstanding principle of safeguarding democratic policymaking in digital governance.

GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the regulation's establishment of binding transparency requirements for platform algorithms, perfectly aligning with their digital accountability principles.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the prohibition of arbitrary business user suspensions as a landmark achievement in curbing platform overreach, mirroring their 2023 Fair Digital Markets Manifesto.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue's balanced dispute issue mechanisms as exemplary protection for SMEs while maintaining platform innovation capacity.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the exclusion of overly burdensome reporting mandates that could disadvantage emerging European platforms, ensuring proportionality with market realities.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the regulation's systemic impact in rebalancing power dynamics between global platforms and EU businesses, fulfilling their decade-long advocacy priorities.

ALDE strongly agrees the regulation’s emphasis on transparency and fairness for business users, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to fostering a competitive yet balanced digital single market.  
ALDE applauds the avoidance of over-regulation, ensuring European platforms remain agile and globally competitive while advancing ALDE’s priority of innovation-driven economic growth.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0238) concerning harmonized rules for the internal market under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first-reading stance to advance legislative procedures. It emphasized the need for coherence with existing EU laws and policies, particularly in internal market, consumer protection, and sectoral areas like industry, energy, and transport. The resolution urged the Commission to ensure any future amendments to its proposal align with Parliament’s adopted position and to resubmit the matter if substantial changes occur. Parliament further directed its President to formally transmit its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and interinstitutional accountability while prioritizing legislative clarity and alignment with EU objectives.

title: Strengthening the competitiveness of the Internal Market by developing the EU customs union and its governance: REPORT on strengthening the competitiveness of the Internal Market by developing the EU Customs Union and its governance
background: The EU Customs Union, foundational to the single market, faced challenges including delays in implementing the Union Customs Code’s digital systems, Brexit’s impact on external borders, divergent customs controls, and rising e-commerce volumes. The Parliament will discuss measures to strengthen the Customs Union’s governance, efficiency, and digital infrastructure to ensure competitiveness and uniform enforcement.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the digitization of customs procedures under the UCC, aligning with their longstanding commitment to a secure and frictionless Internal Market, while proposing enhanced cybersecurity safeguards for delayed IT systems to prioritize operational integrity over arbitrary deadlines.  
EPP approves binding milestones for customs modernization, emphasizing Andreas Schwab’s call for member states to deliver interoperable digital infrastructure to protect €3.7 billion in annual tariff revenues and maintain global competitiveness.  
EPP endorses harmonized customs controls across all member states, advancing their priority to eliminate forum shopping and ensure equal market conditions, as stressed by Adam Szejnfeld’s push for unified legal interpretations.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous post-Brexit customs enforcement as critical to sovereignty, fully supporting the issue’s demand for zero loopholes in EU-UK trade controls to prevent market distortions.  
EPP advocates prioritizing anti-fraud measures in customs reforms, strongly aligning with Seán Kelly’s emphasis on combating financial leaks to protect SMEs and EU fiscal interests.

EFDD conditionally endorses digitization timelines but demands removal of Article 12 provisions enabling post-Brexit customs entanglement, which totally doubts with EFDD's sovereignty principles.  
The issue overlooks critical aspects of democratic oversight by maintaining centralized IT governance inconsistent with EFDD's red lines on national autonomy.  
EFDD requests revisions to strip binding customs harmonization clauses that enable EU-level trade distortion claims against independent UK policies.  
Expansion of Customs Union membership criteria to Eastern Partnership states is rejected as supranational overreach antithetical to EFDD's anti-federalist manifesto.  
Mandatory WTO/WCO coordination mechanisms fail to address EFDD's insistence on unilateral trade defense capabilities for sovereign nations.

ENF completely conflicts the issue's reliance on competitive market mechanisms, which Schaffhauser argues inherently exacerbate regional imbalances by favoring stronger economies.  
ENF rejects the digitization-centric approach as inadequate without structural fiscal tools like customs duties to actively rebalance intra-EU trade disparities.  
The proposal conflicts with ENF's core principle that cooperative markets require tariff-based safeguards, not merely technical harmonization of customs procedures.  
ENF contends the issue overlooks critical sovereignty concerns by prioritizing centralized IT governance rather than national fiscal instruments to protect weaker member states.  
This framework fails to address ENF's demand for mixed solutions combining federal budget transfers and customs duties to counteract single market polarization.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue’s prioritization of a fully digitized Customs Union, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to frictionless trade and bureaucratic efficiency for a competitive single market.  
ALDE applauds the extended IT system implementation timeline to 2025, recognizing this as a pragmatic step to ensure resilient digital infrastructure while preserving intra-EU trade fluidity.  
ALDE completely sanctions harmonized customs controls to eradicate forum shopping, effectively advancing their manifesto goal of equitable market access for SMEs and consumers.  
ALDE highlights the critical need for binding IT project milestones, proposing an amendment to Article 12 to mandate member state transparency reports on quarterly progress toward the 2025 deadline.  
ALDE strongly promotes post-Brexit customs sovereignty safeguards, urging explicit clauses in Section 5 to fortify jurisdictional integrity against third-country risks.

SD supports with suggestions the issue’s emphasis on digitizing customs procedures, advising binding IT implementation milestones and increased funding to address delays, as highlighted by Maria Grapini’s urgency on digital infrastructure.  
SD advises stricter enforcement of third-country compliance with EU obligations, particularly regarding Turkey’s unresolved commitments to Cyprus, aligning with Kώστας Μαυρίδης’s call for conditionality in trade upgrades.  
SD emphasizes the need to harmonize customs controls to prevent market distortions, echoing Lidia Geringer de Oedenberg’s focus on standardized processes to protect SMEs and ensure fair competition.  
SD highlights the importance of robust anti-corruption measures in customs operations, aligning with the issue’s anti-fraud goals and Maria Grapini’s warnings about non-compliant goods.  
SD calls for transparent progress reporting on IT system delays, urging amendments to Article 5 to mandate quarterly updates, reflecting concerns over fragmented governance and accountability.

ECR strongly accepts the issue's digital modernization priorities, aligning perfectly with their commitment to blockchain integration and streamlined IT systems for frictionless trade.  
ECR endorses harmonized customs controls while proposing to raise the de minimis threshold for e-commerce to reduce SME burdens, noting current trials demonstrate this balance of security and efficiency.  
ECR emphasizes enhanced post-Brexit customs collaboration with the UK, effectively advancing protection for export-reliant sectors like Vlaamse havens and 1-in-40 Flemish jobs.  
ECR backs anti-fraud measures but urges targeted controls at Greece-Albania/North Macedonia borders to combat illegal alcohol imports and food mislabeling practices.  
ECR approves funding increases while demanding binding IT milestones to end recurring delays, ensuring the Customs Union meets 2025 implementation goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical importance of a fully operational EU Customs Union for safeguarding the single market, ensuring frictionless trade, protecting EU financial interests, and enhancing the EU’s global negotiating position. It emphasized the necessity of digitizing customs procedures under the Union Customs Code (UCC), noting that 98% of customs declarations are already electronic, but highlighted delays in implementing 17 essential IT systems, necessitating an extension of the transitional period beyond the original 2020 deadline to 2025. The resolution expressed concern over fragmented governance structures, insufficient transparency in reporting delays, and risks posed by the UK’s withdrawal, urging no loopholes in customs controls post-Brexit. It called for streamlined IT project management, binding milestones, and increased funding, including €842.8 million (2018 prices) for the 2021-2027 Customs Programme, alongside national resource commitments. The Parliament stressed harmonizing controls to prevent trade distortions like "forum shopping," enhancing SME accessibility, and addressing rising low-value e-commerce imports (growing 10-15% annually). It advocated for improved coordination with international bodies like the WTO and WCO, stronger anti-fraud measures, and potential expansion of the Customs Union to Eastern Partnership countries. Lastly, it urged the Commission to ensure transparent progress reporting, avoid repeated delays, and prioritize sovereignty in customs IT infrastructure to secure EU economic, fiscal, and security interests.

title: Unfair trading practices in the food supply chain: REPORT on unfair trading practices in the food supply chain
background: Persistent reports of unfair trading practices in the EU food supply chain, driven by power imbalances between large retailers and SMEs/farmers, structural market concentration, and divergent national regulatory approaches, prompted institutional attention. The Parliament will discuss measures to address business-to-business inequities and ensure fair competition across the food sector.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees binding EU legislation to prohibit unfair trading practices, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to safeguarding farmers and SMEs through equitable market frameworks.  
EPP approves establishing independent enforcement bodies with investigatory powers, mirroring the UK Groceries Code Adjudicator model, to ensure confidential complaint mechanisms and penalties for non-compliance.  
EPP proposes enhancing the Late Payment Directive’s enforcement as a complementary measure to new rules, ensuring SMEs face no additional burdens while addressing payment delays.  
EPP strongly agrees strengthening producer organizations’ collective bargaining power, which directly advances EPP’s priority of empowering agricultural communities against concentrated retail dominance.  
EPP endorses cross-border harmonization of fair trading standards to prevent forum shopping, ensuring the issue’s goals align with EPP’s vision for a unified internal market.

GREEN_EFA fully promotes the issue’s binding EU legislation to eradicate unfair trading practices, perfectly aligning with their commitment to dismantling corporate dominance in agri-food systems.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the demand to address market concentration, emphasizing how retailer oligopolies contradict fair competition principles central to their economic justice agenda.  
GREEN_EFA fully promotes strengthening producer organizations for collective bargaining, recognizing this as critical to rebalancing power dynamics harming smallholders and rural communities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on independent enforcement bodies with investigatory powers, a mechanism long advocated in their campaigns for supply chain accountability.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the urgency for the Commission to adopt even more ambitious protections for SMEs and farmers, framing this as a necessary evolution rather than opposition to the issue’s framework.

ALDE strongly upholds the issue’s binding EU legislation to eliminate unfair trading practices, aligning with their commitment to fair competition and protecting SMEs vital to Europe’s agricultural diversity.  
ALDE endorses the UK-inspired enforcement model, emphasizing confidential complaint mechanisms and penalties as critical to balancing power asymmetries in the food supply chain.  
ALDE applauds the focus on strengthening producer organizations’ collective bargaining power, a direct reinforcement of their longstanding advocacy for SME empowerment in single market governance.  
ALDE approves the transparency measures and competition rule revisions, noting these align with their priorities to curb retailer monopolies and ensure fair pricing across markets.  
ALDE proposes specifying penalty tiers in Article 4 to deter large-scale UTPs while maintaining proportionality for minor infractions, enhancing enforcement without opposing the issue’s core framework.

SD completely supports the issue's binding EU legislation proposal, perfectly aligning with SD's longstanding commitment to eradicating power imbalances through enforceable market rules.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for independent enforcement bodies, effectively advancing SD's priority of protecting farmers from exploitative pricing and territorial constraints.  
SD completely supports cross-border enforcement harmonization, recognizing its critical role in preventing forum shopping and safeguarding Azores-style regional agricultural viability.  
SD perfectly supports strengthening producer organizations' bargaining power, a transformative step toward SD's vision of equitable supply chain relationships.  
SD completely supports mandatory price transparency tools, seeing them as essential to counteracting unsustainable below-cost selling practices in dairy and meat sectors.

ECR strongly approves the binding EU legislation to prohibit unfair trading practices, aligning with ECR's commitment to safeguarding SMEs and farmers from exploitative market dominance.  
ECR approves the issue's emphasis on producer organizations as a vital tool to rebalance negotiation power for small agricultural producers across member states.  
ECR highlights the critical need to strengthen national enforcement bodies with investigatory powers, proposing enhanced funding mechanisms in Article 6 to ensure swift implementation.  
ECR endorses cross-border harmonization measures to prevent forum shopping, noting this aligns with ECR's advocacy for equitable market conditions in single market governance.  
ECR urges explicit inclusion of "fear factor" mitigation strategies in Annex II to protect suppliers from retaliatory contract terminations during complaints.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s binding EU legislation to combat below-cost pricing, aligning with their condemnation of market practices that "arrasam produtores" (crush producers) through dumping.  
GUE_NGL advises amending Article 2 to explicitly prohibit cross-border sales below production costs, addressing cases like Central European cheese sold in Portugal at prices below milk input costs.  
GUE_NGL proposes strengthening competition rules to dismantle retailer-owned brands’ monopolistic control, countering the "pulsão imperial" (imperial drive) of large distributors.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes expanding price transparency tools to track production-to-shelf cost disparities, ensuring accountability for "preços impossíveis" (impossible prices) harming farmers.  
GUE_NGL highlights the need for stricter penalties in Annex III against territorial supply constraints, which exacerbate power imbalances criticized as "nívelar por baixo" (leveling downward) working conditions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over widespread unfair trading practices (UTPs) in the EU food supply chain, particularly harming farmers, SMEs, and microenterprises, which constitute 99.1% of the sector. UTPs—including forced payments for non-beneficial services, territorial supply constraints, late payments, and exploitative pricing—stem from power imbalances exacerbated by market concentration, with large retailers and processors leveraging dominance over weaker suppliers. The sector, vital to the EU economy, employs 47 million people, contributes 7% of EU GDP (€1.05 billion market value), and faces crises in dairy, meat, and produce sectors due to unsustainable practices like selling below production costs. Despite voluntary initiatives like the Supply Chain Initiative (SCI), which lacks enforcement, anonymity, and farmer participation, UTPs persist, causing reduced investment, innovation, and food waste while limiting consumer choice. The resolution urges binding EU legislation to prohibit UTPs, enforce fair practices, and establish independent national enforcement bodies with investigatory powers, modeled after the UK Groceries Code Adjudicator, to ensure confidential complaints and penalties. It emphasizes strengthening producer organizations (POs) for collective bargaining, enhancing transparency via price monitoring tools, and revising competition rules to address retailer-owned brands’ anti-competitive risks. Cross-border cooperation and harmonization are critical to prevent forum shopping and ensure equitable market conditions, safeguarding farmers’ viability and consumer interests.

title: Towards improved single market regulation: REPORT on Towards improved single market regulation
background: Persistent challenges to EU integration, including post-2008 economic strains, migration pressures, and Brexit negotiations, alongside concerns over regulatory fragmentation and compliance gaps in cross-border trade, shaped calls for streamlined governance. The Parliament will discuss measures to improve regulatory efficiency and compliance frameworks within the single market.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely advocates the issue's enforcement mechanisms for product compliance, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to a streamlined single market free from bureaucratic barriers.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the harmonization of penalties and centralized surveillance database, recognizing these measures as critical to eliminating regulatory fragmentation while maintaining high consumer and environmental standards.  
EPP applauds the 50% inspection increase target by 2025, which effectively advances their priority of rigorous market oversight without imposing redundant legislation on businesses.  
EPP strongly accepts mandatory digital traceability tools, viewing them as essential to modernizing enforcement practices in line with their advocacy for digital economy competitiveness.  
EPP entirely advocates the issue’s focus on stakeholder dialogue and impact assessments, reflecting their principle of evidence-based policymaking that balances market efficiency with citizen protection.

SD rejects the issue’s centralized database proposal as incompatible with decentralized technological innovations like Hungary’s QR code traceability system, which it fails to mandate.  
This fundamentally disapproves with SD’s principle that consumer protection requires real-time, grassroots digital tools rather than top-down data repositories.  
The proposal overlooks critical SD priorities such as binding EU-wide metrics to assess legislation effectiveness, a gap explicitly criticized in the debate.  
SD opposes the issue’s inspection quotas for neglecting mandatory consumer education programs, which Tibor Szanyi deemed essential for rights enforcement.  
The market surveillance framework is inconsistent with SD’s demand for AI-driven solutions to empower vulnerable consumers, not merely increase bureaucratic inspections.

ECR totally promotes the issue’s emphasis on harmonizing enforcement practices and reducing fragmented national rules, which perfectly aligns with their commitment to streamlining cross-border trade and minimizing bureaucratic costs for businesses.  
The issue’s push for a centralized EU-wide surveillance database resonates perfectly with ECR’s priority of fostering transparent, interoperable systems that empower SMEs to compete without disproportionate compliance hurdles.  
ECR applauds the focus on stricter oversight of online marketplaces as a critical step to eliminate unfair competition from non-compliant products, directly advancing their goal of protecting SMEs from market distortions.  
The call for enhanced coordination among national authorities aligns seamlessly with ECR’s advocacy for subsidiarity, ensuring enforcement respects national parliamentary sovereignty while maintaining single market integrity.  
ECR fully supports the issue’s balanced approach to environmental and consumer protections, recognizing that robust yet pragmatic standards prevent overregulation while safeguarding vulnerable groups and market trust.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the need to strengthen enforcement and market surveillance to ensure product compliance with EU safety, environmental, and consumer protection standards. It called for enhanced coordination among national authorities, stricter controls on non-compliant products—particularly in high-risk sectors like toys, electronics, and machinery—and a 50% increase in inspections by 2025. The resolution emphasized harmonizing penalties for violations, improving customs checks to prevent unsafe imports, and establishing a centralized EU-wide database for surveillance data by 2023. It also urged mandatory product recalls for dangerous items, better traceability through digital tools like QR codes, and stricter oversight of online marketplaces, requiring platforms to proactively remove non-compliant listings. Additionally, the resolution highlighted the importance of protecting vulnerable consumers, addressing environmental risks from non-compliant products, and allocating sufficient funding and training for enforcement agencies to tackle emerging challenges like AI-driven market abuses.

title: Addressing product safety in the Single Market: REPORT on addressing product safety in the single market | A9-0207/2020 | European Parliament
background: The EU's 2001 General Product Safety Directive, unchanged despite rising e-commerce, emerging technologies (AI, IoT, robotics), and increased non-compliant products from third countries, created gaps in addressing digital-era risks and cross-border online sales. The Parliament will discuss modernizing product safety frameworks to address technological advancements and market integration challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely upholds the modernization of EU product safety frameworks, perfectly aligning with their commitment to consumer protection and global standard-setting influence.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's expansion of "safe product" definitions to include AI and IoT, addressing emerging technological risks as highlighted in Benoît Lutgen's intervention.  
EPP strongly endorses enhanced border surveillance measures and mandatory RAPEX integration for online platforms, echoing Lutgen's call for stricter controls on third-country imports, particularly from China.  
EPP applauds the cybersecurity-by-design mandates for connected devices, which advance their priority of preemptive risk mitigation in digital markets.  
EPP absolutely upholds the allocation of MFF funds to strengthen market surveillance, recognizing its critical role in crisis response as demonstrated during COVID-19.

ECR entirely promotes the urgent modernization of the General Product Safety Directive, perfectly aligning with their commitment to regulatory agility in the digital age. The 20-year legislative stagnation directly contradicts ECR's principles of market-responsive governance.  

ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on embedding cybersecurity in connected devices, recognizing this as critical for protecting consumer data rights while maintaining EU technological competitiveness against third-country products.  

The issue effectively advances ECR's priority of enforcing rigorous safety standards for non-EU imports, particularly by mandating checks that prevent unfair competition from jurisdictions with lower consumer protection thresholds.  

ECR strongly agrees integrating online marketplaces into the RAPEX alert system, viewing this as essential for creating equivalent safety obligations between digital and traditional retail environments as outlined in their digital single market strategy.  

This aligns perfectly with ECR's advocacy for sustainable innovation, endorsing IoT solutions that optimize energy consumption while demanding lifecycle safety assessments for AI-enhanced products to balance ecological and consumer protection goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the need to modernize EU product safety frameworks to address emerging technologies, digitalization, and cross-border e-commerce challenges, emphasizing that the single market for goods generates 25% of EU GDP and 75% of intra-EU trade. It highlighted the outdated General Product Safety Directive (2001/95/EC), inadequate coverage of non-harmonized products (one-third of EU goods), and risks from unsafe or non-compliant products, particularly from third countries and online marketplaces. The resolution called for revising definitions of "product" and "safe product" to include AI, IoT, robotics, and software updates, ensuring safety throughout a product’s lifecycle, and embedding cybersecurity by design in connected devices. It urged harmonized market surveillance rules, increased resources for authorities, mandatory checks on third-country imports, and alignment of online/offline safety standards, including mandatory obligations for online platforms under the Digital Services Act to remove unsafe products and integrate with the RAPEX alert system. The Parliament stressed the need for EU-wide AI standards, risk-based conformity assessments, regulatory sandboxes, and mandatory cybersecurity certifications for high-risk products. It advocated traceability improvements via blockchain, enhanced recall mechanisms, and cooperation with third countries to enforce safety rules in trade agreements. Additionally, it emphasized funding under the 2021-2027 MFF to strengthen market surveillance and consumer protection, particularly for medical equipment during crises like COVID-19.

title: Implementation of the Construction Products Regulation: REPORT on the implementation of Regulation (EU) No 305/2011 laying down harmonised conditions for the marketing of construction products (the Construction Products Regulation) | A9-0012/2021 | European Parliament
background: The Construction Products Regulation (2011) established harmonized marketing rules for EU construction products but faced implementation challenges including standardization delays linked to ECJ interpretation, sectoral fragmentation, and evolving sustainability demands within a sector employing 18 million people contributing 9% of EU GDP. The Parliament will discuss regulatory implementation challenges affecting internal market functioning and product safety standards.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely promotes the issue's emphasis on harmonized standards and CE marking clarity, perfectly aligning with their commitment to a unified internal market for construction products.  
EPP proposes strengthening market surveillance mechanisms through blockchain-enabled Smart DoP systems to enhance transparency while maintaining SME accessibility across borders.  
EPP perfectly aligns with calls to resolve legislative overlaps with the Ecodesign Directive, ensuring regulatory coherence without duplicative compliance burdens for manufacturers.  
EPP entirely promotes integrating earthquake resilience requirements into product declarations, as highlighted by recent tragedies, to advance life-preserving safety standards in construction.  
EPP supports establishing expedited EU court procedures for SMEs as an enhancement opportunity to deliver swift issue of cross-border trade disputes under the CPR framework.

SD fundamentally approves the issue’s emphasis on harmonizing standards to eliminate market fragmentation, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to a unified internal market and equitable conditions for SMEs.  
SD perfectly aligns with the integration of sustainability goals through the New Green Deal and circular economy principles, advancing SD’s priority of green transformation in construction.  
SD fully supports the modernization of CE marking and digital tools like Blockchain for compliance checks, which enhance transparency and match SD’s advocacy for tech-driven regulatory efficiency.  
SD endorses the issue’s call for regionally adaptable minimum requirements, ensuring pragmatic safety standards that reflect SD’s focus on context-sensitive policy implementation.  
SD fully aligns with strengthened market surveillance mechanisms, particularly for online sales, reinforcing SD’s stance on fair competition and consumer protection in the digital age.

GREEN_EFA totally sanctions the issue’s emphasis on integrating health, safety, and environmental performance requirements into construction standards, perfectly aligning with their commitment to ecological transition and sustainable industry practices.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prioritization of circularity in construction products as a critical step toward reducing waste and resource consumption, effectively advancing their manifesto goals for a zero-emissions economy.  
GREEN_EFA strongly approves the issue’s focus on worker and consumer safety, recognizing it as foundational to their advocacy for social justice and equitable labor conditions in green industries.
