GREEN_EFA highlights the urgency of leveraging this regulatory framework to accelerate the construction sector’s alignment with climate neutrality targets, mirroring their long-standing demand for binding sustainability benchmarks.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the issue’s call to avoid failing future generations as a vital reinforcement of their intergenerational justice principles, ensuring construction policies serve both ecological resilience and societal well-being.

ECR totally advocates the issue’s prioritization of digital tools like Blockchain and Smart DoP, perfectly aligning with ECR’s commitment to modernizing compliance processes and enhancing market transparency through technological innovation.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the call for rigorous market surveillance, particularly targeting third-country imports sold online, to uphold safety standards and ensure fair competition within the EU internal market.  
ECR fully supports harmonizing technical standards across Member States, emphasizing the urgency of eliminating unjustified national barriers that fragment the internal market and hinder post-pandemic recovery.  
ECR emphasizes the issue’s alignment with maintaining cost efficiency in construction products, ensuring regulatory changes do not burden consumers amid pandemic-related economic strains.  
ECR strongly endorses clarifying CE marking requirements to prevent misinterpretation, reinforcing the issue’s goal of ensuring the mark solely denotes regulatory compliance rather than quality endorsement.

ID fundamentally advocates the issue’s prioritization of CE marking clarity and strict market surveillance, perfectly aligning with ID’s longstanding commitment to eliminating fraudulent product certifications and ensuring fair competition for European manufacturers.  
ID highlights the issue’s emphasis on digital tools like Blockchain as critical to enhancing compliance transparency, which directly advances ID’s priority of modernizing regulatory frameworks while supporting post-pandemic economic recovery.  
ID applauds the focus on resolving legislative overlaps with directives like Ecodesign, aligning with ID’s principle of regulatory coherence to prevent bureaucratic burdens on SMEs.  
ID underscores the necessity of harmonizing standards to maintain a "common technical language," reflecting ID’s unwavering stance against unilateral national barriers that distort the internal market.  
ID commends the integration of environmental and safety requirements without cost inflation, mirroring ID’s balanced approach to sustainability and economic competitiveness in the construction sector.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the need to revise the Construction Products Regulation (CPR) to address challenges in harmonizing standards, enhancing market surveillance, and ensuring the free movement of construction products within the EU. The resolution highlighted that the construction sector employs 18 million people and contributes 9% to EU GDP, underscoring the urgency of resolving stagnation in standard development, with only 12 of 444 harmonized standards updated in four years. It emphasized maintaining a "common technical language" to align Member States’ building requirements with product performance declarations, while advocating for CE marking clarity to prevent misinterpretation as a quality mark and urging inclusion of minimum safety and environmental requirements. The resolution called for digital solutions like Blockchain and Smart Declaration of Performance (DoP) to streamline compliance checks and improve transparency, alongside stronger market surveillance, particularly for online sales and third-country imports, to ensure product safety and fair competition. It stressed the importance of clarifying overlaps between CPR and other EU laws (e.g., Ecodesign Directive) and integrating sustainability goals without inflating costs, while considering SMEs’ needs and COVID-19 impacts, such as supply shortages and reduced investments. Key recommendations included optimizing the internal market, modernizing CE marking, strengthening surveillance, resolving legislative overlaps, and adopting digital tools to support economic recovery and regulatory coherence.

title: Implementation of the Toy Safety Directive: REPORT on the implementation of Directive 2009/48/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council on the safety of toys (Toy Safety Directive) | A9-0349/2021 | European Parliament
background: The 2009 EU Toy Safety Directive aimed to harmonize safety standards and ensure child protection. A 2020 Commission evaluation identified gaps in chemical regulations, inconsistent market surveillance, and challenges from e-commerce growth and emerging technologies like connected toys. The Parliament will discuss the directive’s implementation and areas requiring regulatory enhancement.

stances.stance:
EPP completely endorses the elimination of age-based chemical distinctions and CMR derogations, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to child-centric safety standards that prevent manufacturer circumvention.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's demand for blockchain-enabled traceability and AI-powered market surveillance, advancing EPP's digital governance priorities while ensuring fair competition.  
EPP completely endorses mandatory cybersecurity protocols for connected toys, effectively addressing risks highlighted by smart teddy bear vulnerabilities through EN 71-12:2017-aligned technical specifications.  
EPP perfectly supports converting the Directive into a Regulation to expedite chemical limit updates, reflecting EPP's longstanding advocacy for harmonized enforcement against third-country non-compliance.  
EPP fully aligns with cross-border injury databases and DSA-GPSD integration, strengthening EPP's vision of a child-safe digital single market through real-time product recall coordination.

SD entirely agrees the elimination of age-based chemical limits, perfectly aligning with evidence that manufacturers circumvent current distinctions and children’s equal vulnerability to toxic substances.  
SD unequivocally supports converting the TSD into a Regulation to expedite chemical safety updates, ensuring swift alignment with advancements like the EU Chemical Strategy for Sustainability.  
SD perfectly aligns with mandating EN 71-12:2017 nitrosamine standards and endocrine disruptor inclusion, addressing critical gaps in child protection identified in Safety Gate reports.  
SD entirely agrees applying the Digital Services Act to hold platforms accountable for removing non-compliant toys, reflecting urgent market surveillance needs for third-country imports sold online.  
SD perfectly aligns with expanding the TSD’s scope to cover cybersecurity risks in connected toys, ensuring lifelong safety for AI-driven or data-collecting products as emphasized in debate examples.

RENEW totally endorses the elimination of CMR derogations, aligning perfectly with RENEW's commitment to child safety and science-based chemical regulation.  
RENEW perfectly supports harmonizing nitrosamine limits with EN 71-12:2017, advancing RENEW's priority of eliminating regulatory fragmentation in the single market.  
RENEW totally endorses converting the Directive into a Regulation, which aligns with RENEW's longstanding advocacy for swift, uniform legal frameworks across the EU.  
RENEW strongly affirms the inclusion of endocrine disruptors and combination effects, effectively advancing RENEW's alignment with the EU Chemical Strategy for Sustainability.  
RENEW fully supports mandatory blockchain traceability and e-commerce accountability, reflecting RENEW's manifesto goals for tech-driven market surveillance and fair competition.

GREEN_EFA absolutely agrees the elimination of age-based distinctions in chemical limits, perfectly aligning with their principle that toxicity thresholds must protect all children equally regardless of manufacturing labels.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand to prohibit all CMR substances without derogation, advancing their decades-long campaign against carcinogenic and endocrine-disrupting chemicals in children’s environments.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely agrees expanding the directive’s scope to include connected toys, effectively addressing cybersecurity risks and data privacy concerns raised in their 2023 “Safe Digital Childhood” manifesto.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to consolidate fragmented chemical regulations under the TSD, a systemic approach matching their advocacy for unified “zero tolerance” policies on hazardous substances.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely agrees converting the directive into a regulation to accelerate enforcement, mirroring their 2021 position paper demanding immediate applicability of chemical safety updates.

ECR fundamentally approves the issue’s elimination of CMR derogations and uniform chemical limits, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eradicating preventable childhood exposure to hazardous substances.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the demand to convert the TSD into a Regulation, recognizing this as essential to accelerating safety updates and eliminating transposition inconsistencies across member states.  
ECR strongly advocates the integration of endocrine disruptors and combination effects into the TSD, reflecting their alignment with the EU Chemical Strategy’s precautionary principles.  
ECR fundamentally approves leveraging blockchain and Pan-European Injury Databases as critical advancements to strengthen traceability and evidence-based risk assessments.  
ECR applauds the issue’s expansion of scope to address "grey zone" products and cybersecurity risks, effectively advancing their priority of holistic child protection in physical and digital environments.

ID fundamentally advocates the issue’s emphasis on blockchain technology for traceability, perfectly aligning with ID’s commitment to leveraging innovation for consumer safety and market transparency.  
ID perfectly aligns with the call to address accessibility for children with disabilities, reflecting ID’s priority to ensure inclusive play opportunities through robust regulatory frameworks.  
ID fundamentally advocates the elimination of age-based chemical distinctions, as this harmonizes with ID’s unwavering stance on uniform safety standards to protect all children equally.  
ID perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for enhanced market surveillance, particularly through digital tools, to uphold fair competition and child safety across both physical and online markets.  
ID fundamentally advocates the integration of endocrine disruptor regulations into the TSD, advancing ID’s long-term advocacy for science-driven chemical safety reforms in line with the EU Chemical Strategy.

GUE_NGL entirely agrees the elimination of age-based chemical distinctions, perfectly aligning with their mandate to protect all children equally from hazardous substances.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with the call to integrate endocrine disruptors and combination effects into the TSD, advancing their commitment to precautionary health protections.  
GUE_NGL entirely agrees converting the directive into a Regulation, ensuring swift enforcement of cybersecurity and data safeguards for connected toys as emphasized in their debate priorities.  
GUE_NGL perfectly aligns with sustainability labeling requirements, reflecting their advocacy for durable, repairable toys that reduce waste and promote intergenerational use.  
GUE_NGL entirely agrees strict market surveillance enhancements under Regulation 2019/1020, resonating with their demand for robust authorities to combat unsafe online toy sales.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the need to revise Directive 2009/48/EC on toy safety (TSD) to address critical gaps, particularly in chemical safety, market surveillance, and e-commerce risks. Key issues include the TSD’s chemical provisions, which allow derogations for carcinogenic, mutagenic, or reprotoxic (CMR) substances and maintain age-based distinctions for chemical limits (e.g., toys for children under 36 months), despite evidence of manufacturers circumventing these rules. The resolution calls for eliminating derogations for CMRs, aligning nitrosamine limits with stricter German standards and EN 71-12:2017 (0.5 mg/kg for nitrosamines, 1.0 mg/kg for nitrosatable substances), and removing age distinctions to apply uniform chemical limits. It highlights the fragmentation of chemical regulations across multiple EU laws (e.g., REACH, RoHS), advocating consolidation under the TSD to streamline compliance. Endocrine disruptors and combination effects of chemicals, unaddressed in the current TSD, should be incorporated, reflecting the EU Chemical Strategy for Sustainability. Market surveillance improvements are urged, citing the 2020 EU Safety Gate report where toys accounted for 27% of unsafe product notifications. The resolution supports implementing Regulation 2019/1020 to enhance enforcement, including online marketplaces, and leveraging technologies like blockchain for traceability. E-commerce challenges require aligning the Digital Services Act and revised General Product Safety Directive to hold platforms accountable for removing non-compliant toys. The TSD should be converted into a Regulation to expedite updates and avoid transposition delays, while expanding its scope to cover mechanical risks, allergenic fragrance labeling, and "grey zone" products (non-toys resembling toys). Additional measures include establishing a Pan-European Injury Database, introducing sustainability labels (lifespan, reparability), and addressing cybersecurity risks in connected toys. The resolution emphasizes strict enforcement to protect children, ensure fair competition, and adapt to scientific advancements.

title: Covid-19: EU coordination of health assessments and risk classification and the consequences on Schengen and the single market: JOINT MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on COVID-19: EU coordination of health assessments and risk classification, and the consequences for Schengen and the single market | RC-B9-0257/2020 | European Parliament
background: The COVID-19 pandemic prompted divergent national responses across EU Member States, including uncoordinated health measures, border controls, and varying risk classifications, disrupting Schengen and the single market while highlighting disparities in ECDC data harmonization. The Parliament will discuss EU-level coordination of health assessments and risk management to address impacts on free movement and market integrity.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely advocates the issue's mandate for a unified color-coded risk classification system, which aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to preserving Schengen through science-based regional coordination rather than national border closures.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for harmonized 15-minute rapid testing protocols and mutual recognition of results, recognizing this as critical to maintaining essential worker mobility and cross-border economic activity in line with single market principles.  
EPP unequivocally supports the establishment of the European Health Response Mechanism (EHRM), seeing it as an essential institutional advancement to operationalize EPP's 2020 manifesto pledge for crisis-resilient EU health governance.  
EPP emphasizes the issue's demand for interoperable contact-tracing apps by October 2020 as a non-negotiable tool to balance free movement with pandemic containment, reflecting EPP's digital single market priorities.  
EPP celebrates the issue's focus on restoring Schengen functionality through coordinated regional thresholds as the definitive solution to prevent fragmented national measures, thereby advancing EPP's core doctrine of "resilient Europe".

SD fully advocates the issue’s call for harmonized risk assessment through ECDC-driven color-coded mapping, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to data-driven EU health governance and restoring trust in coordinated crisis responses.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand for mutual recognition of COVID-19 tests and interoperable contact-tracing apps, advancing SD’s priority to eliminate fragmentation in free movement while safeguarding public health.  
SD fully supports the creation of a European Health Response Mechanism, recognizing it as essential to strengthen healthcare resilience and secure medical supply chains across the single market.  
SD endorses the issue’s emphasis on harmonized quarantine periods and traveler locator forms, which directly address SD’s call to simplify compliance and rebuild Schengen functionality.  
SD applauds the focus on rapid implementation of Next Generation EU funds, viewing this as critical to mitigating economic disparities exacerbated by uncoordinated national measures.

RENEW fully agrees the harmonized risk classification system as perfectly aligning with our vision for a borderless Europe grounded in scientific coordination  
RENEW perfectly supports the mandated mutual recognition of rapid tests across Member States, advancing our single market priorities while protecting public health  
RENEW unreservedly champions the interoperable contact-tracing framework as critical to restoring free movement in line with our digital governance agenda  
RENEW wholeheartedly approves the binding timelines for lifting internal border controls, which mirror our Schengen reform commitments since 2019  
RENEW unequivocally backs the EHRM creation as a transformative step toward pan-European health preparedness that our parliamentary group has long advocated

GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the issue’s harmonized color-coded risk classification, perfectly aligning with their commitment to equal treatment of EU citizens and dismantling arbitrary border barriers.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call for interoperable contact-tracing apps and harmonized passenger locator forms, advancing their priority of data-protected, cross-border health governance.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports the binding coordination of quarantine periods and testing protocols, effectively addressing their demand for science-based parity in pandemic responses across the single market.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the issue’s emphasis on restoring Schengen functionality, resonating with their manifesto pledge to protect free movement for families and essential workers.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the European Health Response Mechanism as a critical step toward transparent vaccine procurement and crisis preparedness, mirroring their long-standing advocacy for accountable pharmaceutical governance.

ECR strongly agrees the harmonized color-coded risk classification system, aligning with their commitment to preserving Schengen and the internal market through coordinated yet subsidiarity-respecting EU action.  
ECR endorses mutual recognition of COVID-19 tests and interoperable contact-tracing apps, emphasizing their critical role in safeguarding cross-border workers and families while maintaining free movement.  
ECR proposes enhancing transparency in vaccine procurement by disclosing negotiation team compositions and contract terms, ensuring accountability without compromising procurement efficiency.  
ECR approves the issue’s focus on avoiding universal health criteria, stressing that the European Health Response Mechanism must respect national assessments of healthcare capacity and epidemiological risks.  
ECR strongly agrees the call to minimize travel costs for essential workers, urging explicit safeguards against financial burdens arising from testing requirements in cross-border professions.

ID rejects the issue's premise of EU health coordination as fundamentally incompatible with ID's insistence on national sovereignty over border controls and pandemic management.  
ID opposes the color-coded risk map proposal, arguing it institutionalizes EU overreach into health policies that "every country manages autonomously" (Sardone), creating bureaucratic hurdles instead of restoring Schengen integrity.  
ID condemns the issue's silence on immigration-driven COVID risks, emphasizing Italy's "forced exposure to health dangers" from uncontrolled arrivals without EU burden-sharing—a critical oversight contradicting ID's border security priorities.  
ID rejects the call for interoperable contact-tracing apps, citing the Strasbourg/Brussels seat dispute (Joron) as proof that EU institutions "disregard treaties when convenient," undermining trust in cross-border data systems.  
ID opposes harmonized quarantine rules as unworkable given Austria's "unlawful disregard for constitutional and EU law" (Mayer), demonstrating that centralized health measures erode national democratic accountability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over fragmented and uncoordinated COVID-19 responses among Member States, emphasizing the need for harmonized measures to safeguard public health, free movement, and the internal market. It stressed the pandemic’s transition to a chronic phase, requiring coordinated risk management, and highlighted disparities in testing capacities, data collection, and recognition of test results across borders. The resolution called for swift adoption of the Commission’s proposal for a color-coded risk map (green, orange, red, grey) based on regional ECDC data, updated weekly, to guide travel restrictions and ensure transparency. It urged Member States to align quarantine periods, testing protocols (including 15-minute rapid tests), and definitions of COVID-19 cases and deaths, while ensuring mutual recognition of tests and minimizing travel disruptions for essential workers. The Parliament advocated for interoperable contact-tracing apps by October 2020, harmonized passenger locator forms compliant with data protection rules, and a European Health Response Mechanism (EHRM) to strengthen crisis preparedness. It highlighted the economic impact of border closures, urging refunds for canceled flights under Regulation (EC) No 261/2004, resilient supply chains for critical goods, and swift implementation of Next Generation EU recovery funds. The resolution emphasized restoring a fully functional Schengen area, avoiding prolonged internal border controls, and protecting consumer rights against scams and unsafe products. It called for a "resilient Europe" strategy to bolster healthcare systems, secure medical supplies, and ensure the internal market’s sustainability, while upholding proportionality, non-discrimination, and fundamental rights in all measures.

title: Digital Markets Act: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on contestable and fair markets in the digital sector (Digital Markets Act) | A9-0332/2021 | European Parliament
background: Growing concerns over dominant digital platforms’ market power, insufficient competition safeguards, and consumer risks in the EU’s digital single market, alongside calls for updated regulatory frameworks to address systemic online challenges, prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss establishing equitable competition rules and enhanced consumer protections for large online platforms acting as market gatekeepers.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly endorses the issue’s expansion of economic operator definitions and due diligence obligations, perfectly aligning with EPP’s commitment to eradicating hazardous third-party products and ensuring transparent digital market practices.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s lifecycle assessment and reparability mandates, advancing EPP’s priority to embed environmental sustainability as a core pillar of the EU’s digital transformation.  
EPP firmly endorses the strict liability framework for non-compliant online marketplace products, reflecting EPP’s unwavering stance that illegal offline activities must be equally prohibited and penalized in digital spaces.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s risk-based inspection protocols and cross-border enforcement mechanisms, reinforcing EPP’s vision of a harmonized, fraud-resistant digital single market.  
EPP firmly endorses the proportionality of fines relative to corporate turnover, ensuring accountability for systemic market distortions while safeguarding SME competitiveness through simplified compliance pathways.

SD fully supports the DMA’s structural measures under Article 16, which perfectly align with S&D’s commitment to dismantling monopolistic practices and ensuring accountability for systemic market abuses by Big Tech.  
SD applauds the issue’s mandate for interoperable messaging services, advancing S&D’s priority of empowering consumer choice and breaking platform lock-in effects that exploit user data.  
SD emphasizes the DMA’s role in ending surveillance capitalism, as highlighted by its prohibitions on non-consensual data practices, which directly reflect S&D’s manifesto goals for a human-centric digital economy.  
SD underscores the necessity of robust enforcement resources for national authorities, framing this as critical to transforming the DMA from a “paper tiger” into a tool that delivers tangible protections for SMEs and users.  
SD calls for stringent transparency in lobbying activities, proposing enhanced Annex 1 disclosures to prevent covert Big Tech influence, thereby reinforcing the issue’s integrity.

GREEN_EFA fully advocates the issue's prioritization of democratic governance over monopolistic tech interests, perfectly aligning with their commitment to regulatory frameworks that ensure market transparency and consumer protection as outlined in Articles 2 and 16.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the mandate for interoperable messaging services and privacy protections, endorsing amendments that enable user choice and challenge centralized digital ecosystems as highlighted in revisions to Annex 1.  
GREEN_EFA fully supports independent researcher access to platform data, which addresses information asymmetry and advances public interest goals under the issue’s risk assessment protocols in Article 5.  
GREEN_EFA endorses stringent liability measures for non-compliant third-party products, reinforcing their stance against covert tracking and algorithmic manipulation in online marketplaces.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s alignment with fundamental rights over commercial interests, particularly through prohibitions on intrusive surveillance advertising as critical to curbing big tech’s societal influence.

ECR strongly upholds the Digital Markets Act's provisions enhancing competition and market access for SMEs, aligning perfectly with ECR's commitment to fostering innovation and reducing barriers in the digital single market.  
ECR approves the issue’s emphasis on consumer protection through stricter liability for non-compliant third-party products, effectively advancing ECR's priority of ensuring transparent and fair online marketplaces.  
ECR proposes strengthening algorithmic transparency requirements to safeguard freedom of expression, ensuring content moderation tools respect satire and political discourse while maintaining compliance with the regulation.  
ECR applauds the risk-based inspection mandates and cross-border enforcement cooperation as critical steps to harmonize implementation, matching ECR's 2023 manifesto goals for regulatory efficiency.  
ECR emphasizes the need for robust dialogue between national authorities and the Commission to ensure consistent enforcement, enhancing the issue’s framework without opposing its core objectives.

ID strongly advocates the DMA’s provisions for protecting whistleblowers and enhancing market fairness, aligning with their commitment to accountability and challenging dominant tech monopolies.  
ID applauds the emphasis on interoperability of messaging services as a step toward reducing reliance on non-European platforms, though proposes further measures to mandate open standards for greater consumer choice.  
ID endorses the integration of environmental sustainability through lifecycle assessments, consistent with their advocacy for eco-digital policies that support European SMEs.  
ID recommends strengthening safeguards in crisis response mechanisms to ensure democratic oversight and prevent undue restrictions on free expression, building on the issue’s market surveillance framework.  
ID urges expanded investment in European digital infrastructure and startups, mirroring historical initiatives like Airbus, to complement the DMA’s regulatory framework and foster homegrown tech leadership.

GUE_NGL strongly approves the issue’s emphasis on curbing big tech monopolies through stricter market surveillance (Articles 7-9) and fines proportional to turnover (Article 16), aligning with their commitment to dismantling exploitative corporate power.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 2 to explicitly include “user anonymity rights” and “opt-out mechanisms for surveillance advertising” as core consumer protections, enhancing digital sovereignty.  
GUE_NGL approves the prioritization of environmental sustainability via lifecycle assessments (Article 5), which mirrors their Green Deal advocacy for systemic ecological accountability in tech sectors.  
GUE_NGL highlights the need to strengthen Annex 1’s technical standards to mandate algorithmic transparency, preventing toxic content amplification while maintaining support for SME compliance simplifications.  
GUE_NGL urges stricter liability frameworks for third-party products in online marketplaces, aligning with their anti-surveillance capitalism stance, but suggests expanding reparability clauses to cover software-driven devices.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s proposed regulation (COM(2020)0842) aimed at harmonizing EU internal market rules, emphasizing amendments to strengthen consumer protection, market transparency, and regulatory coherence. Key amendments included expanding definitions of economic operators (Article 2), enhancing due diligence obligations for product compliance (Article 3), and reinforcing traceability requirements through digital tools. The resolution introduced stricter criteria for market surveillance (Articles 7-9), mandated risk-based inspections, and emphasized cooperation among national authorities. It prioritized environmental sustainability by integrating lifecycle assessments (Article 5) and promoting reparability of goods. Amendments to Annex 1 clarified technical standards, while new provisions addressed emerging challenges in online marketplaces, including stricter liability for non-compliant third-party products. The Parliament also called for robust enforcement mechanisms, including fines proportional to company turnover (Article 16), and stressed the need for consistent implementation across member states. The resolution underscored alignment with the European Green Deal and digital transition goals, ensuring the regulation supports SMEs through simplified compliance procedures and centralized guidance.

title: Digital Services Act: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on a Single Market For Digital Services (Digital Services Act) and amending Directive 2000/31/EC | A9-0356/2021 | European Parliament
background: The European Commission's 2020 proposal for a Digital Services Act aimed to modernize the 2000 e-Commerce Directive, addressing evolving online platform challenges, market fragmentation, and gaps in regulating illegal content, consumer protection, and systemic risks posed by large digital actors. The Parliament will discuss establishing harmonized rules for digital services to enhance safety, accountability, and transparency across the EU single market.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the harmonized consumer protection frameworks in Articles 1-8, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to a secure digital single market where illegal offline activities remain illegal online.  
EPP approves the centralized enforcement database under Article 22 as critical for cross-border regulatory coherence, effectively advancing EPP's priority of eliminating jurisdictional fragmentation.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 15’s risk assessment protocols to include quarterly audits of emerging AI tools, ensuring proactive mitigation without opposing the issue’s core monitoring obligations.  
EPP strongly endorses the disinformation crisis mechanisms referenced by Krzysztof Hetman, noting their alignment with EPP’s 2021 cybersecurity strategy to counter foreign interference.  
EPP emphasizes the need for dedicated Commission task forces to implement Eva Maydell’s future-proofing vision, ensuring continuous adaptation to novel business models under Article 35’s review clauses.

SD entirely promotes the issue's structural intervention measures under Article 31, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to dismantling big tech's anti-competitive dominance through enforceable penalties like corporate breakups.  
SD perfectly aligns with the mandated messaging interoperability requirements in Article 15, advancing SD's vision of user-centric digital ecosystems where platform lock-in strategies become obsolete.  
SD applauds the prohibition of surveillance-based advertising to minors under Recital 97a as a landmark achievement in protecting vulnerable groups from predatory data practices.  
SD commends the centralized enforcement database (Article 22) as critical infrastructure for realizing SD's long-standing demand for EU-wide regulatory coherence against fragmented national implementations.  
SD strongly sanctions the issue's explicit rejection of big tech's shadow lobbying tactics through Article 48 transparency mechanisms, upholding SD's principle of democratic accountability in digital policymaking.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally approves the issue’s paradigm shift toward democratic control over monopolistic tech platforms, perfectly aligning with their commitment to prioritizing public interest over corporate power as articulated in Articles 1-2 and Recital 97a.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the mandatory risk assessments under Article 15 and independent researcher data access, recognizing these as critical tools to dismantle algorithmic harms and information asymmetry highlighted in Alexandra Geese’s defense of evidence-based regulation.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally approves interoperability mandates for messaging services under amended Articles 4-8, viewing this as foundational to Marcel Kolaja’s vision of decentralizing digital ecosystems and safeguarding privacy against surveillance capitalism.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly supports the 4% turnover penalties in Article 31 and sustainability clauses in Recitals 36a/40b, echoing Kim Van Sparrentak’s call to curb big tech’s unchecked expansion into healthcare, education, and data exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally approves the centralized EU enforcement database (Article 22) as essential to realizing cross-border accountability, a prerequisite for their long-standing advocacy of pan-European digital sovereignty.

ECR strongly advocates the issue's establishment of uniform digital market rules under Articles 1-2, aligning with their advocacy for reduced trade barriers and economic prosperity through modernized business models.  
ECR approves the enhanced consumer safeguards in Articles 19-20, particularly protections for online purchasers and vulnerable groups, which advance their commitment to balancing market growth with user rights.  
ECR proposes strengthening national consumer protection authorities under Article 31 enforcement mechanisms to ensure consistent cross-border application, reflecting their emphasis on subsidiarity in regulatory frameworks.  
ECR highlights the need to refine Article 15 risk assessment protocols to explicitly safeguard free expression from algorithmic overreach, ensuring humor and political discourse remain protected as per constitutional traditions.  
ECR applauds the centralized EU database in Article 22 as a critical transparency tool, effectively advancing their priority of harmonized enforcement while maintaining member state operational autonomy.

ID supports the inclusion of whistleblower protections in the issue, aligning with safeguards for vulnerable groups under Articles 19-20.  
ID advises amending Article 15 to ensure citizen reports receive equal priority as trusted flagger notifications, preventing institutional bias in content moderation.  
ID expresses concern over the crisis response mechanism in Articles 48-52, advocating for parliamentary oversight to prevent undue restrictions on free expression during emergencies.  
ID recommends revising Article 31 to reinstate higher penalty thresholds, ensuring meaningful deterrence against non-compliance by major platforms.  
ID supports market transparency goals but urges expanding Recitals 36a and 40b to include EU-funded digital infrastructure initiatives, fostering homegrown tech champions.

GUE_NGL completely challenges the issue's failure to prohibit surveillance capitalism's core profit mechanisms, as Article 8 leaves targeted advertising intact despite Clare Daly's demand for opt-out rights.  
GUE_NGL rejects the omission of mandatory anonymity options in Article 2's service provider definitions, directly contradicting their digital privacy principles.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue's Article 15 for permitting addictive content algorithms without requiring ethical alternatives, enabling continued mental health harms.  
GUE_NGL declares the 4% turnover fines in Article 31 insufficient to dismantle big tech's exploitative data models they denounce as "motivated by profit."  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's structural failure to democratize platform governance through user-controlled algorithms, a core Left demand unmet in Articles 19-20.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a proposed regulation (COM(2020)0825) aimed at harmonizing internal market rules under Article 114 TFEU, adopting extensive amendments to strengthen consumer protection, market transparency, and regulatory coherence. Key substantive changes include expanding definitions of regulated entities (Articles 1-2), enhancing obligations for compliance monitoring (Articles 4-8), and introducing stricter data-sharing requirements between member states and EU bodies (Articles 10-12). The resolution mandates risk assessments for emerging technologies (Article 15), reinforces safeguards for vulnerable groups (Articles 19-20), and establishes a centralized EU database for enforcement tracking (Article 22). It introduces penalties for non-compliance, including fines up to 4% of annual turnover (Article 31), and requires biennial reporting on implementation (Article 35). Amendments also prioritize environmental sustainability (Recitals 36a, 40b) and gender equality (Recital 97a), while streamlining cross-border cooperation mechanisms (Articles 48-52). The Parliament instructed the Commission to revise its proposal if substantial changes occur and emphasized alignment with the European Economic and Social Committee and Committee of the Regions’ 2021 opinions.

title: Right to repair: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the right to repair | B9-0175/2022 | European Parliament
background: Growing e-waste volumes, consumer demand for durable goods, and EU circular economy targets under the European Green Deal, alongside existing directives on product standards and consumer rights, highlighted gaps in product repairability frameworks. The Parliament will discuss establishing comprehensive measures to strengthen consumer access to product repairs and sustainable consumption practices.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the issue’s integration of sustainability with innovation, emphasizing the need to balance repairability mandates with technological advancement to maintain EU competitiveness.  
EPP endorses harmonized repairability labeling as a critical step toward consumer empowerment, aligning with circular economy principles under the European Green Deal.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 4 by mandating granular impact assessments on SMEs to prevent disproportionate compliance costs while maintaining environmental goals.  
EPP emphasizes that extending legal guarantees must prioritize product durability metrics over blanket timelines to incentivize quality manufacturing practices.  
EPP applauds the focus on green public procurement as a market driver for repaired goods, reflecting EPP’s commitment to resource-efficient industrial transformation.

SD supports extending legal guarantees to reflect actual product lifespans and proposes amending the Sale of Goods Directive to mandate durability thresholds by product category.  
SD advises introducing price regulation mechanisms for spare parts, suggesting amendments to cap costs at 30% of the original product price to address affordability barriers highlighted in Croatia.  
SD proposes requiring manufacturers to provide opt-out options for software updates that reduce device performance, with mandatory pre-installation disclosure of potential impacts.  
SD endorses financial incentives such as VAT reductions for repair services and tax credits for manufacturers establishing repair networks to align economic signals with circular economy goals.  
SD highlights the need for stricter penalties against planned obsolescence in Ecodesign revisions, including digital forms, to complement the issue’s anti-waste measures.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the issue's mandate for durable product design through Ecodesign Directive revisions, perfectly aligning with their circular economy principles demonstrated in David Cormand's emphasis on ending "consumption-as-destruction" models.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the prohibition of software-induced obsolescence, as Kim Van Sparrentak demanded, recognizing this as critical to halting Europe's 53 million tonnes of annual e-waste.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees enforceable repair rights and standardized repairability labels, mirroring Sara Matthieu's call to transform consumer "gut feelings" about short-lived devices into legal guarantees.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the job creation potential in local repair sectors, amplifying Manuela Ripa's argument that repair sovereignty strengthens both employment and EU resource independence.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the issue's systemic shift from linear waste models, recognizing as Ripa noted that only repairable product designs can achieve true circularity under the Green Deal.

ECR supports the issue's emphasis on consumer repair access but advises amending Article 4 to require impact assessments ensuring repair mandates don't increase product prices disproportionately.  
ECR endorses harmonized repairability labels but proposes revising the Ecodesign Directive revisions to explicitly protect trade secrets in repair documentation.  
ECR advises adding provisions to eliminate cross-border service barriers for repair professionals to enhance market competition and affordability.  
ECR cautions that extended legal guarantees should not restrict consumers' right to replacement under warranty during high inflation periods.  
ECR requests the Commission analyze lifecycle emissions of repaired vs new eco-designed products to prevent unintended environmental harm.

GUE_NGL strongly endorses mandating accessible spare parts and repair manuals, aligning perfectly with their commitment to environmental justice and reducing Europe’s e-waste crisis.  
GUE_NGL applauds the issue’s condemnation of programmed obsolescence as a scourge on consumers and the planet, effectively advancing their priority for sustainable consumption.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Article 4 to explicitly require affordability benchmarks for spare parts, ensuring cost barriers do not undermine repair accessibility.  
GUE_NGL endorses harmonized repairability labels as a transformative step to empower consumers, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for transparent, eco-conscious purchasing.  
GUE_NGL fully backs extending legal guarantees to strengthen consumer rights, recognizing this as pivotal for shifting from disposable culture to circular systems.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a comprehensive right to repair framework to advance sustainability, consumer rights, and circular economy goals under the European Green Deal. Emphasizing that 79% of EU citizens support requiring manufacturers to facilitate device repairs and 77% prefer repairing over replacing items, the resolution highlighted the potential for job creation in repair sectors and addressed the 53 million tonnes of global e-waste generated in 2019. Key proposals included revising the Ecodesign Directive to mandate durable, repairable product design, ensuring access to spare parts and repair manuals for consumers and independent repairers, and requiring software updates for digital goods to prevent premature obsolescence. The resolution called for harmonized consumer information on product repairability, durability, and software update availability, including standardized labels, digital passports, and QR codes. It urged extending legal guarantees beyond the current two-year minimum under the Sale of Goods Directive, incentivizing repair over replacement through financial measures, and promoting green public procurement favoring repaired or refurbished products. The Commission was tasked with assessing joint manufacturer-seller liability, banning destructive disposal of unsold goods, and conducting impact analyses to balance sustainability, consumer protection, and business competitiveness, particularly for SMEs. The initiative aligns with the Sustainable Products Initiative and aims to reduce waste, enhance resource efficiency, and empower consumers through transparent, sustainable choices.

title: Strengthening the single market: the future of free movement of services: REPORT on strengthening the single market: the future of free movement of services | A9-0250/2020 | European Parliament
background: The EU services sector, contributing 73% of GDP and 74% of employment, faced persistent barriers like fragmented regulations, administrative complexities, and incomplete implementation of the Services Directive (2006) and related frameworks, exacerbated by COVID-19 economic impacts. The Parliament will discuss enhancing the single market’s free movement of services, addressing regulatory and enforcement challenges.

stances.stance:
EPP fully promotes the issue's prioritization of enforcing the Services Directive and Professional Qualifications Directive as essential to unlocking €297 billion in economic potential, perfectly aligning with their agenda for post-COVID recovery and SME competitiveness.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the demand for accelerated mutual recognition of qualifications across all education levels, recognizing this as critical for cross-border service provision in key sectors like engineering and healthcare.  
EPP strongly promotes the elimination of territorial restrictions and language barriers through digital tools like the Single Digital Gateway, reflecting their longstanding commitment to frictionless administrative processes for SMEs.  
EPP fully promotes stricter proportionality tests and EU-wide social security coordination as mechanisms to harmonize market freedoms with worker protections, mirroring their balanced approach to economic integration and social rights.  
EPP applauds the issue’s emphasis on SMET’s role in aligning single market reforms with the European Green Deal, which directly advances their sustainability goals while strengthening cross-border service ecosystems.

SD fundamentally advocates the issue’s integration of service freedom with robust worker protections, perfectly aligning with SD’s longstanding commitment to preventing social dumping and enforcing the country-of-destination principle for fair labor standards.  
SD perfectly aligns with the emphasis on mutual recognition of professional qualifications grounded in quality criteria, effectively advancing SD’s priority to harmonize labor mobility while safeguarding worker rights.  
SD strongly sanctions the protection of services of general economic interest, such as healthcare and public transport, recognizing their exclusion from unrestricted market forces as critical to social cohesion.  
SD fundamentally advocates the creation of an EU-wide social security number, a measure that directly advances SD’s goals to combat fraud and strengthen cross-border worker protections.  
SD applauds the issue’s rejection of fragmented digital solutions like the e-service card, aligning perfectly with SD’s insistence that fairness requires systemic safeguards over market-driven shortcuts.

RENEW fundamentally agrees the issue's prioritization of digitalizing cross-border procedures for SMEs, perfectly aligning with our digital single market acceleration goals  
RENEW perfectly aligns with the demand to expand the European Professional Card to engineering professions, enhancing labor mobility as outlined in our 2024 policy framework  
RENEW fully supports the strict enforcement of proportionality tests under the Proportionality Test Directive, recognizing this as essential to dismantling protectionist barriers  
RENEW applauds the integration of Single Digital Gateway enhancements, which directly advance our manifesto pledge for seamless digital service provision  
RENEW unequivocally backs the SMET's mandate to align single market reforms with the European Green Deal, mirroring our climate-positive economic agenda

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's market integration priorities as firmly opposeing with their mandate to protect essential public services like healthcare and municipal utilities from liberalization pressures.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the emphasis on eliminating territorial restrictions and national regulations, which risks dismantling local authority over critical social infrastructure such as water systems and public transport.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the issue's failure to explicitly safeguard high environmental and labor standards in cross-border service provisions, a core requirement for any single market reforms.  
GREEN_EFA warns that digitalization of administrative procedures through tools like the Single Digital Gateway prioritizes corporate efficiency over democratic accountability in service delivery.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's silence on preventing privatization of public services as dangerously inconsistent with their commitment to universal access and social cohesion.

ECR supports the issue's emphasis on enforcing the Services Directive and digitalizing cross-border procedures to reduce fragmentation, aligning with their priority to eliminate barriers for SMEs.  
ECR advises expanding the scope of mutual recognition reforms to include analysis of best practices in service productivity, as highlighted by significant disparities between member states.  
ECR endorses the call to eliminate discriminatory territorial restrictions against service providers, noting such barriers disproportionately affect Polish businesses and undermine single market cohesion.  
ECR proposes accelerating the reduction of regulated professions across the EU, citing evidence that excessive protectionism costs consumers €5 billion annually while benefiting select producers.  
ECR expresses concern that certain EU policies like the revised Posting of Workers Directive contradict single market principles by creating disproportionate burdens for newer member states' workers and firms.

ID rejects the issue's enforcement mechanisms for service market liberalization, absolutely opposeing with ID's defense of national sovereignty over social security systems as seen in Markus Buchheit's condemnation of EU-wide social security numbers.  
ID opposes the Proportionality Test Directive's application, echoing Virginie Joron's warning against dismantling France's "trop restrictive" social protections through EU-mandated barrier reduction targets.  
ID condemns the Green Deal integration into single market reforms, aligning with Markus Buchheit's rejection of "die Wirtschaft zerstörenden Umweltschutzgedanken" that override national industrial priorities.  
ID disputes the pandemic-era logic for deeper integration, supporting Jean-Lin Lacapelle's argument that COVID-19 exposed the dangers of "libéralisme" and necessitated border controls rather than service market expansion.  
ID challenges the infringement procedures against Italy's tourism sector regulations, reflecting Marco Campomenosi's critique of EU overreach during economic recovery as creating "incertezza e paura per le imprese."

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's deregulatory approach to services as totally challengeing with their commitment to affordable housing and public welfare.  
GUE_NGL opposes the erosion of national regulatory powers, which would exacerbate housing crises by enabling platforms like Airbnb to destabilize urban rental markets.  
GUE_NGL condemns the proposal for prioritizing corporate interests over workers' needs, particularly in failing to safeguard accessible housing for essential service workers like nurses and police.  
GUE_NGL highlights the issue's incompatibility with social equity, as liberalizing service markets without robust public oversight risks deepening inequality.  
GUE_NGL asserts that the issue overlooks critical protections for local communities, instead advancing a neoliberal agenda harmful to social cohesion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about persistent barriers hindering the single market for services, which accounts for 73% of EU GDP and 74% of employment but contributes only 20% to intra-EU trade. It stressed that deepening integration could unlock up to €297 billion (2% of EU GDP) and address post-COVID-19 economic recovery, noting that 14 million manufacturing-related jobs depend on services. Key priorities included enforcing the Services Directive and Professional Qualifications Directive to reduce fragmentation, digitalizing cross-border procedures for SMEs, and eliminating unjustified national regulations, territorial restrictions, and language barriers. The resolution urged Member States to fully implement revised Posting of Workers Directive protections, accelerate mutual recognition of qualifications across all education levels, and expand the European Professional Card to more professions, including engineering. It called for stricter enforcement of proportionality tests under the Proportionality Test Directive, improved compliance with the Cross-Border Healthcare Directive, and enhanced accessibility under the European Accessibility Act. The Parliament highlighted the need to leverage digital tools like the Single Digital Gateway and Points of Single Contact to streamline administrative processes, while urging vigilance against COVID-19-related service restrictions. It pushed for the Single Market Enforcement Task Force (SMET) to establish transparent metrics, address non-tariff barriers, and align reforms with the European Green Deal and social rights. Additionally, the resolution emphasized public procurement harmonization for green services, stricter monitoring of social security coordination, and an EU-wide social security number to combat fraud. Criticizing delayed transposition of directives in 20 Member States, it demanded annual progress reports, updated single market scoreboards, and stakeholder-driven evaluations to close enforcement gaps and achieve a sustainable, inclusive single market.

title: Tackling non-tariff and non-tax barriers in the single market: REPORT on tackling non-tariff and non-tax barriers in the single market | A9-0336/2021 | European Parliament
background: Persistent non-tariff barriers in the EU single market, including regulatory disparities, territorial supply constraints, and administrative burdens, hindered cross-border trade and SME competitiveness. EU institutions identified challenges through communications (2020-2021) and studies, noting incomplete legislation implementation and market fragmentation. The Parliament will discuss measures to address barriers affecting single market integration.

EPP applauds the issue's focus on harmonizing professional qualifications and services sector integration, directly advancing their 2023 priority to unlock €713 billion in untapped Single Market potential.

SD perfectly aligns with the call for enhanced mutual recognition of professional qualifications, reflecting SD's 2023 agenda priorities on labor mobility and SME competitiveness.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's deregulatory framework as incompatible with their demand for harmonization prioritizing ecological and social protections over market efficiency.

GREEN_EFA opposes territorial supply constraint removal without binding requirements for corporate due diligence on labor rights and environmental impacts.

ECR strongly accepts the issue’s focus on practical solutions for regulatory harmonization and digitalization, aligning with their commitment to enhancing SME competitiveness in the Single Market without increasing regulatory burdens.  
ECR endorses the call for accelerated mutual recognition of professional qualifications across member states, proposing that implementation timelines be shortened to fully unlock service sector potential.

ECR highlights the necessity of completing the Single Market’s integration, particularly in services, to achieve projected GDP growth while resisting domestic protectionist measures that distort competition.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about persistent barriers undermining the EU Single Market, which sustains 56 million jobs and 25% of EU GDP, with the agri-food sector as the largest manufacturing employer. It highlighted non-tariff barriers (NTBs), including regulatory disparities, inconsistent enforcement of EU law, territorial supply constraints (TSCs), and administrative burdens disproportionately affecting SMEs—71% of which faced market access denials under mutual recognition systems. The resolution urged stronger enforcement via tools like SOLVIT and the Single Digital Gateway, harmonization of standards, and addressing gaps in services sector integration, noting 24 identified restrictions under the Services Directive. It called for eliminating discriminatory practices, enhancing mutual recognition of professional qualifications, and improving digitalization, including the Digital Services Act and Digital Markets Act. The Parliament stressed aligning Single Market policies with climate neutrality and social rights, while addressing COVID-19 impacts through measures like the EU Digital COVID Certificate and a proposed Single Market Emergency Instrument. It criticized Member States for pandemic-related trade barriers and insufficient implementation of EU law, citing 800 single-market infringement cases in 2019. The resolution emphasized the need for coordinated enforcement, transparency in the Single Market Enforcement Taskforce (SMET), and leveraging NextGenerationEU funds to strengthen resilience, innovation, and e-government solutions.

title: Towards a more sustainable single market for business and consumers: REPORT Towards a more sustainable single market for business and consumers | A9-0209/2020 | European Parliament
background: Growing resource depletion, waste proliferation, and post-pandemic economic vulnerabilities underscored EU sustainability goals under the Green Deal and Circular Economy Action Plan. Consumer demand for durable goods, concerns over product lifespans, and regulatory gaps in e-commerce compliance highlighted market challenges. The Parliament will discuss aligning single market policies with circular economy principles, consumer rights, and sustainable production frameworks.

stances.stance:
EPP rejects the mandatory spare parts requirements as firmly rejecting with their principle of maintaining industrial competitiveness and SME viability.  
EPP opposes the proposed binding measures against product destruction as overlooking critical aspects of inventory management realities for small businesses.  
The issue's harmonized labeling schemes contradict EPP's stance on minimizing bureaucratic burdens, risking disproportionate compliance costs for manufacturers.  
EPP fundamentally disputes the legal guarantee extensions, arguing they fail to address supply chain complexities and import control deficiencies highlighted in Benoît Lutgen's China trade concerns.  
The digital product passport mandate conflicts with EPP's emphasis on subsidiarity, as articulated in Sven Simon's warnings about EU overreach creating "bürokratische Monster".

SD fundamentally approves the prohibition of planned obsolescence, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to consumer protection and ecological transition.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for standardized pre-contractual repairability metrics and accessible spare parts, effectively advancing SD’s priority of empowering sustainable consumer choices.  
SD fundamentally approves the binding measures to prevent destruction of reusable goods, reflecting SD’s manifesto pledge to eliminate wasteful production practices across the single market.  
SD perfectly aligns with the harmonized repair score labeling proposal, which directly supports SD’s mission to eradicate greenwashing through transparent, real-use durability benchmarks.  
SD fundamentally approves the universal charger mandate for electronic devices, a critical step toward reducing e-waste that SD has championed since 2021.

RENEW supports the right to repair framework but advises amending Article 7 to explicitly include software updates for smart devices under guarantee extensions.  
RENEW endorses harmonized labeling yet proposes a phased implementation with sector-specific flexibility to prevent disproportionate burdens on SMEs.  
RENEW highlights concerns that centralized spare part distribution requirements could strain smaller manufacturers unless supplemented with regional logistics subsidies.  
RENEW urges strengthening the digital product passport mandate by integrating blockchain traceability for critical minerals in Annex III.  
RENEW applauds the ban on destroying unsold goods as aligned with circular economy priorities outlined in their 2023 policy agenda.

ECR opposes fundamentally the mandatory repairability requirements and extended legal guarantees, asserting that such regulations impose unnecessary administrative burdens inconsistent with their advocacy for market-driven innovation.  
ECR rejects the harmonized labeling schemes and digital product passports, arguing these measures centralize decision-making contrary to ECR's principle of subsidiarity and consumer-led market evolution.  
ECR disputes the premise that binding measures against reusable goods destruction are needed, maintaining that existing entrepreneurial incentives sufficiently address sustainability without EU intervention.  
ECR criticizes the issue's reliance on green public procurement mandates, viewing this as state overreach into private sector competitiveness.  
ECR challenges the assumption that citizens prefer regulatory solutions, citing consumer capability to drive sustainability through informed choices without EU mandates.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to transition towards a sustainable single market by enhancing product durability, repairability, and consumer rights, aligning with the European Green Deal and circular economy goals. It emphasized integrating sustainability with competitiveness, urging measures to combat planned obsolescence, including clear pre-contractual information on product lifespan (determined via objective, real-use metrics) and reparability, alongside harmonized labeling schemes like a repair score or environmental performance index. The resolution highlighted that 79% of EU citizens support mandatory repairability for digital devices, while 59% were unaware of the EU’s two-year legal guarantee, underscoring the need for better consumer education. It called for a "right to repair," including free access to repair information, standardized spare parts, reasonable pricing, and incentives for repair over replacement, alongside extending legal guarantees to match product lifespans. The Parliament advocated for stricter market surveillance to ensure compliance with EU standards, particularly for e-commerce, and proposed a digital "product passport" to track sustainability metrics. It urged binding measures to prevent the destruction of reusable goods, promoted second-hand markets through transferred guarantees, and stressed green public procurement to drive demand for sustainable products. Addressing misleading environmental claims ("greenwashing"), the resolution demanded stricter enforcement and transparency, supported by 77% of citizens preferring repair to replacement. Funding via the Single Market Programme and R&D investments were emphasized to support SMEs, innovation, and awareness campaigns, while digital infrastructure’s environmental footprint was flagged for assessment. The Parliament also highlighted the role of sustainable public procurement in reducing supply chain dependencies and fostering climate neutrality, urging ambitious sector-specific criteria and reporting mechanisms.
